name: Abel
description: Biblical second son of Adam and brother of Cain.
ref_descr: Raised by Jesus from Limbo into Paradise.

name: Abraham the Patriarch
description: Important biblical figure.
ref_descr: Raised by Jesus from Limbo into Paradise.

name: Absalom and Ahithophel
description: Absalom was the rebellious son of King David who was incited by Ahithophel, the king's councilor.
ref_descr: Bertran de Born compares his fomenting with the "malicious urgings" of Ahithophel.

name: Achan
description: Ancient Israelite who stole from Jericho during Joshua's conquest. He was stoned to death for the theft. (Joshua 7:1–26)
ref_descr: Cited by souls on the terrace of the greedy as an example of greed.

name: Acheron
description: The mythological Greek underworld river over which Charon ferried souls of the newly dead into Hades.
ref_descr: The "melancholy shore" encountered.

name: Acheron
description: The mythological Greek underworld river over which Charon ferried souls of the newly dead into Hades.
ref_descr: Formed from the tears of the statue of the Old Man of Crete.

name: Achilles
description: The greatest Greek hero in the Trojan War. An account well known in the Middle Ages has him killed by Paris after having been lured with the promise of Priam's daughter Polyxena.
ref_descr: Found amongst the sexual sinners.

name: Achilles
description: The greatest Greek hero in the Trojan War. An account well known in the Middle Ages has him killed by Paris after having been lured with the promise of Priam's daughter Polyxena.
ref_descr: Remembered by Virgil for having been educated by Chiron.

name: Achilles
description: The greatest Greek hero in the Trojan War. An account well known in the Middle Ages has him killed by Paris after having been lured with the promise of Priam's daughter Polyxena.
ref_descr: His abandonment of Deidamia and his only son, at the urging of Ulysses, to go to the war against Troy.

name: Achilles
description: The greatest Greek hero in the Trojan War. An account well known in the Middle Ages has him killed by Paris after having been lured with the promise of Priam's daughter Polyxena.
ref_descr: Statius identifies himself in Purgatory as the author of the Achilleid, an unfinished epic poem on the life of Achilles.

name: Acre
description: Ancient city in Western Galilee, it was the last Christian possession in the Holy Land, finally lost in 1291. Inf. XXVII, 86.
ref_descr: Latin line used to maintain the rhyme scheme with neighboring Latin quotations.

name: Adam
description: According to the Bible, the first man created by God.
ref_descr: His "evil seed".

name: Adam
description: According to the Bible, the first man created by God.
ref_descr: Our "first parent", raised by Jesus from Limbo into Paradise.

name: Adam
description: According to the Bible, the first man created by God.
ref_descr: Dante sees the tree in the Garden of Eden which caused the fall of Adam and Eve. (See Genesis 3.)

name: Adam
description: According to the Bible, the first man created by God.
ref_descr: Speaks to Dante.

name: "Adhaesit pavimento anima mea"
description: ("My soul cleaveth unto the dust.") (Psalm 119:25; 118:25 in the Vulgate.)
ref_descr: Recited penitentially by prostrate souls on the terrace of greed in Purgatory.

name: Aegina
description: A Greek island between Attica and Argolis in the Saronic Gulf. According to tradition it was named by its ruler Aeacus—son of Zeus and Aegina, daughter of the river-god Asopus—after his mother. In Ovid's Metamorphoses (VII, 501–660), Aeacus, tells of a terrible plague inflicted by a jealous Juno (Hera), killing everyone on the island but Aeacus; and how he begged Jupiter (Zeus) to give him back his people or take his life as well. Jupiter then turned the islands ants into a race of men called the Myrmidons, some of whom Achilles ultimately led to war against Troy.
ref_descr: "... all Aegina's people sick ... when the air was so infected ... received their health again through seed of ants.", compared with "the spirits languishing in scattered heaps" of the tenth Malebolge.

name: Aeneas
description: Hero of Virgil's epic poem Aeneid, his descent into hell is a primary source for Dante's own journey.
ref_descr: Son of Anchises, fled the fall of Troy.

name: Aeneas
description: Hero of Virgil's epic poem Aeneid, his descent into hell is a primary source for Dante's own journey.
ref_descr: "Father of Sylvius", journey to Hades, founder of Rome.

name: Aeneas
description: Hero of Virgil's epic poem Aeneid, his descent into hell is a primary source for Dante's own journey.
ref_descr: When Dante doubts he has the qualities for his great voyage, he tells Virgil "I am no Aeneas, no Paul".

name: Aeneas
description: Hero of Virgil's epic poem Aeneid, his descent into hell is a primary source for Dante's own journey.
ref_descr: Seen in Limbo.

name: Aeneas
description: Hero of Virgil's epic poem Aeneid, his descent into hell is a primary source for Dante's own journey.
ref_descr: "Rome's noble seed".

name: Aeneas
description: Hero of Virgil's epic poem Aeneid, his descent into hell is a primary source for Dante's own journey.
ref_descr: Founder of Gaeta.

name: Aesop
description: A semi-legendary Greek fabulist of whom little reliable is known. A famous corpus of fables is traditionally assigned to him.
ref_descr: His fable of the frog and the mouse is mentioned.

name: Africanus
description: Agnomen of Publius Cornelius Scipio Africanus (236–183 BCE), the Roman general who defeated the Carthaginian general Hannibal in the Second Punic War.
ref_descr: His triumphant reception in Rome mentioned.

name: Agathon
description: Greek poet of the 5th century BCE.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Agapetus
description: Pope from 535 to 536.
ref_descr: In the Heaven of Mercury, the soul of the Emperor Justinian credits Agapetus with correcting him of heretical beliefs.

name: Aglauros
description: Athenian princess who envied her sister's love affair with Hermes. When she attempted to block Hermes' access, he changed her to stone.
ref_descr: Her voice is heard in Purgatory on the terrace of the envious as a lesson in envy.

name: Agnus Dei
description: Liturgical anthem addressed to Jesus as Lamb of God. Sung while the Eucharistic bread is being divided. It ends with "Dona nobis pacem." ("Grant us peace.")
ref_descr: Sung by souls in the terrace of the angry in Purgatory.

name: Ahasuerus
description: Ancient King of Persia according to the Book of Esther. He married Esther, whose uncle was Mordecai. Haman, the prime minister, became enraged at Mordecai for refusing to bow in his presence. Haman then plotted a pogrom of the Jews in the kingdom. The plot was discovered, and Ahasuerus had Haman executed.
ref_descr: Dante has a vision of the execution as he departs the terrace of the angry in Purgatory.

name: Ahasuerus
description: Ancient King of Persia according to the Book of Esther. He married Esther, whose uncle was Mordecai. Haman, the prime minister, became enraged at Mordecai for refusing to bow in his presence. Haman then plotted a pogrom of the Jews in the kingdom. The plot was discovered, and Ahasuerus had Haman executed.
ref_descr: Cited as his own analogy by Bertran de Born.

name: Alba
description: Town in Latium near Rome which founded the Latin League in the early years of Rome.
ref_descr: According to the soul of the Emperor Justinian, the eagle of Roman glory rested in Alba for three centuries.

name: Albert I of Germany
description: Roman-German King (1298–1308) from the Habsburg family. He was King during the events of the Comedy.
ref_descr: Dante refers to him as German Albert ("Alberto tedesco") and condemns him for failing to come south and curb violent conflict in Italy.

name: Alberto da Casalodi
description: Guelph count of Brescia, he was Signore of Mantua during the feuding between Guelphs and Ghibellins. He was ousted in 1273 by his advisor Pinamonte dei Bonacolsi.
ref_descr: His foolishness ("la mattia da Casalodi") in trusting Pinamonte.

name: Albertus Magnus (c. 1197–1280)
description: Dominican friar, scholar, and teacher of Thomas Aquinas.
ref_descr: Standing to the right of Thomas Aquinas in the sphere of the Sun.

name: Alcmaeon
description: Son of Eriphyle, who presumed herself worthy to wear jewelry designed for the gods. Her presumption resulted in her husband's death. Alcmaeon murdered his mother in revenge.
ref_descr: Eriphyle is depicted on the pavement in Purgatory as an example of arrogance.

name: Alcmaeon
description: Son of Eriphyle, who presumed herself worthy to wear jewelry designed for the gods. Her presumption resulted in her husband's death. Alcmaeon murdered his mother in revenge.
ref_descr: Beatrice cites Alcmaeon's act of murder as a moral failure.

name: Tegghiaio Aldobrandi
description: Florentine son of the famous Aldobrando degli Adimari, he was podestà of Arezzo in 1256 and fought at the battle of Montaperti in 1260, where his warnings against attacking the Senese forces went unheeded, and the Florentines were annihilated.
ref_descr: One of a group of famous political Florentines, "who were so worthy ... whose minds bent toward the good", asked about by Dante of Ciacco.

name: Tegghiaio Aldobrandi
description: Florentine son of the famous Aldobrando degli Adimari, he was podestà of Arezzo in 1256 and fought at the battle of Montaperti in 1260, where his warnings against attacking the Senese forces went unheeded, and the Florentines were annihilated.
ref_descr: One of a group of three Florentine sodomites who approach Dante, and are much esteemed by him (see Jacopo Rusticucci).

name: Tegghiaio Aldobrandi
description: Florentine son of the famous Aldobrando degli Adimari, he was podestà of Arezzo in 1256 and fought at the battle of Montaperti in 1260, where his warnings against attacking the Senese forces went unheeded, and the Florentines were annihilated.
ref_descr: Cryptically described as he, "la cui voce nel mondo sù dovria esser gradita" ("whose voice the world above should have valued"), probably an allusion to his councils at Montaperti.

name: Alexander the Great
description: King of Macedon (356–323 BCE) and the most successful military commander of ancient history
ref_descr: Probably the tyrant pointed out by Nessus.

name: Alexander the Great
description: King of Macedon (356–323 BCE) and the most successful military commander of ancient history
ref_descr: Apocryphal story of his adventures in India provide a simile for the punishment of the violent against God in

name: Ali
description: Cousin and son-in-law of Muhammad, and one of his first followers. Disputes over Ali's succession as leader of Islam led to the split of Islam into the sects of Sunni and Shi'a.
ref_descr: He "walks and weeps" in front of Muhammed.

name: Amphiaraus
description: Mythical king of Argos and seer, who although he had foreseen his death, was persuaded to join the expedition of the Seven against Thebes. He was killed while fleeing from pursuers, when Zeus threw a thunderbolt, and the earth opened up and swallowed him.
ref_descr: The story of his death is told.

name: Anagni
description: ancient town in central Italy. Birthplace of Pope Boniface VIII.
ref_descr: In 1303, Philip IV of France invaded Italy and captured Boniface at Anagni.

name: Pope Anastasius II
description: Pope who Dante perhaps mistakenly identified with the emperor Anastasius I and thus condemned to hell as a heretic. Anastasius I was a supporter of Monophysitism, a heresy which denied the dual divine/human nature of Jesus.
ref_descr: Dante and Virgil take shelter behind Anastasius' tomb and discuss matters of theology.

name: Anaxagoras (c. 500–428 BCE)
description: Greek philosopher.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Anchises
description: Father of Aeneas by Aphrodite. In the Aeneid he is shown as dying in Sicily.
ref_descr: Father of Aeneas.
ref: Inf. I, 74, Purg. XVIII, 137, Par. XIX, 132.

name: Loderingo Andalò (c. 1210–1293)
description: Of a prominent Ghibelline family, he held many civic positions. In 1261 he founded the Knights of Saint Mary or Jovial Friars, a religious order recognized by Pope Clement IV. Its mission was to promote peace between warring municipal factions, but its members soon succumbed to self-interest. Together with Catalano dei Malavolti, he shared the position of governor of Florence. Loderingo is extolled for his fortitude in dying by his friend, the poet Guittone d'Arezzo.
ref_descr: Among the hypocrites.

name: Andrea de' Mozzi
description: Chaplain of the popes Alexander IV and Gregory IX, he was made bishop of Florence in 1287 and there remained until 1295, when he was moved to Vicenza, only to die shortly after.
ref_descr: One of a group of sodomites identified by Brunetto Latini to Dante. Brunetto (i.e. Dante) blasts him with particular harshness, calling him "tigna".

name: Anglo-Scottish War
description: the state of endemic conflict between England and Scotland in which neither side could 'remain within their borders'.
ref_descr: cited by the Eagle of divine justice as a matter of shame for Christians,

name: Annas
description: The father-in-law of Caiaphas, he also is called High-Priest. He appears to have been president of the Sanhedrin before which Jesus is said to have been brought.
ref_descr: Among the hypocrites, he suffers the same punishment as Caiaphas.

name: Antaeus
description: Son of Neptune and Gaia. A giant whose invincible strength came from contact with the earth. Hercules killed him by lifting him from the earth and crushing him.
ref_descr: Lowers Dante and Virgil onto the surface of Cocytus.

name: Antenor of Troy
description: Counselor to King Priam of Troy during the events of the Trojan War.
ref_descr: The second ring of Cocytus, where the treacherous to country are punished, is named Antenora.

name: Antigone and Ismene
description: Theban princesses and daughters of Oedipus and Jocasta who appear in several ancient plays.
ref_descr: Residents of Limbo.

name: Antiochus IV Epiphanes (c. 215–163 BCE)
description: Last powerful Seleucid king, he is famous principally for his war against the Maccabees.
ref_descr: Just as he "sold" the High Priesthood to Jason, Philip IV of France "sold" the papacy to Clement V.

name: Apollo
description: Greek god of the sun, music and prophecy who led the Muses, the goddesses who inspired literature and arts.
ref_descr: Dante invokes Apollo to inspire and guide his writing at the opening of the Paradiso.

name: Apulia
description: A region in southeastern Italy bordering the Adriatic Sea in the east, the Ionian Sea to the southeast, and the Strait of Otranto and Gulf of Taranto in the south. In the Middle Ages, it referred to all of southern Italy. The barons of Apulia broke their promise to defend the strategic pass at Ceperano for Manfred, the son of Frederick II, and allowed Charles of Anjou to pass freely into Naples. Manfred was subsequently killed (1266) at the Battle of Benevento, a crucial blow to the Ghibelline cause.
ref_descr: Its "fateful land" as battleground, and Apulia's betrayal.

name: Thomas Aquinas
description: Dominican theologian considered to be one of the greatest scholars of the Church.
ref_descr: Dante claims that he was murdered by Charles of Anjou.

name: Thomas Aquinas
description: Dominican theologian considered to be one of the greatest scholars of the Church.
ref_descr: He introduces wise men in the sphere of the Sun.

name: Thomas Aquinas
description: Dominican theologian considered to be one of the greatest scholars of the Church.
ref_descr: He eulogises St. Francis.

name: Thomas Aquinas
description: Dominican theologian considered to be one of the greatest scholars of the Church.
ref_descr: He condemns Dominicans who have strayed from the true Dominican charism.

name: Arachne
description: In Greek mythology, a woman who challenged Athena to a contest of skill in weaving. Athena destroyed her work and converted the woman into a spider.
ref_descr: Depicted on the pavement in Purgatory as an example of arrogance.

name: Arcolano of Siena
description: A member of the Maconi family, he was a member of the notorious Sienese Spendthrift Club. He fought in the Battle of Pieve al Toppo in 1288, where according to Giovanni Boccaccio, he preferred to die in battle rather than live in poverty.
ref_descr: Probably "Lano", one of two spendthrifts (the other being Jacomo da Sant' Andrea) whose punishment consists of being hunted by female hounds.

name: Arethusa
description: In Greek mythology she was a nymph daughter of Nereus. Running away from a suitor, Alpheus, she was transformed by Artemis into a fountain.
ref_descr: Her transformation, as described in Ovid's Metamophoses (V, 572–641), is compared to the fate of the thieves.

name: Arethusa
description: In Greek mythology she was a nymph daughter of Nereus. Running away from a suitor, Alpheus, she was transformed by Artemis into a fountain.
ref_descr: Geryon's adornments, compared to her weavings.

name: Argia
description: Ancient Theban woman, sister of Deipyle and wife of Polynices.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Argus
description: Giant of ancient Greek mythology with multiple eyes.
ref_descr: Compared to the eyes on the four allegorical beasts in the Pageant of the Church Triumphant.

name: Ariadne
description: Daughter of Minos, king of Crete, who helped Theseus kill the Minotaur, the offspring of Ariadne's mother Pasiphaë and a bull.
ref_descr: Referred to as the sister of the Minotaur.

name: Aristotle
description: 4th-century BCE Greek philosopher whose writings were a major influence on medieval Christian scholastic philosophy and theology, particularly on the works of Thomas Aquinas.
ref_descr: As "il maestro di color che sanno" ("the master of those who know") he is among those encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Aristotle
description: 4th-century BCE Greek philosopher whose writings were a major influence on medieval Christian scholastic philosophy and theology, particularly on the works of Thomas Aquinas.
ref_descr: His Nicomachean Ethics quoted by Virgil.

name: Aristotle
description: 4th-century BCE Greek philosopher whose writings were a major influence on medieval Christian scholastic philosophy and theology, particularly on the works of Thomas Aquinas.
ref_descr: His Physics, referred to by Virgil.

name: Aristotle
description: 4th-century BCE Greek philosopher whose writings were a major influence on medieval Christian scholastic philosophy and theology, particularly on the works of Thomas Aquinas.
ref_descr: Mentioned by Virgil as one "who would—if reason could—have been content".

name: Arles
description: City in the south of France and supposed location of the tombs of Charlemagne's soldiers who fell in the battle of Roncesvalles.
ref_descr: Simile for the tombs in the sixth circle.

name: Arno
description: River which runs through Florence.
ref_descr: Subject of a discourse on the vices of the people of Tuscany.

name: Aruns
description: In Lucan's epic poem Pharsalia, he is the Etruscan seer who prophesies the Civil war, Caesar's victory over Pompey, and its ending in 48 BCE.
ref_descr: Seen among the seers. Dante mentions his cave, which he locates (erroneously) near Luni.

name: "Asperges me" ("Thou shalt sprinkle me")
description: Psalm 51:9 (Psalm 50:9 in the Vulgate Bible). Opening of the Asperges, a hymn sung during the sprinkling of a congregation with Holy Water. "Thou shalt sprinkle me with hyssop, and I shall be cleansed: thou shalt wash me, and I shall be made whiter than snow."
ref_descr: Dante hears the hymn when he is carried through the River Lethe.

name: Athena
description: Greek Goddess of Wisdom. "Pallas" is a widely used epithet for her.
ref_descr: In Purgatory, she is depicted in a pavement carving casting Briareus from Olympus.

name: Athena
description: Greek Goddess of Wisdom. "Pallas" is a widely used epithet for her.
ref_descr: As the goddess of wisdom, she propels his metaphorical sailing ship in the heavens.

name: Athens
description: Major Greek city of antiquity.
ref_descr: Commended by Dante as an example of good government.

name: Atropos
description: The Fate who determines mortals' deaths by cutting their threads.
ref_descr: It is said that sometimes a sinner's soul falls to Cocytus before she cuts their thread, leaving the body to be taken over by a demon.

name: Attila the Hun (c. 406–453)
description: King of the Huns, known in Western tradition as the "Scourge of God".
ref_descr: Pointed out by Nessus.

name: Attila the Hun (c. 406–453)
description: King of the Huns, known in Western tradition as the "Scourge of God".
ref_descr: Confused by Dante with Totila who destroyed Florence in 542.

name: Augustus (63 BCE – 14 CE)
description: The Roman Emperor under whom Virgil found fame as a poet.
ref_descr: Called "the good Augustus" by Virgil.

name: Augustus (63 BCE – 14 CE)
description: The Roman Emperor under whom Virgil found fame as a poet.
ref_descr: Augustus took charge of Virgil's physical and literary remains after his death. "My bones were buried by Octavian."

name: Augustus (63 BCE – 14 CE)
description: The Roman Emperor under whom Virgil found fame as a poet.
ref_descr: His triumphant chariot compared to the chariot in the Pageant of the Church Triumphant.

name: Aurora
description: Roman goddess of dawn
ref_descr: Used as a poetic reference to sunrise in Purgatory.

name: Ave
description: "Ave gratia plena, Dominus tecum." (Hail, highly favored one, the Lord is with you.) Words addressed by the angel Gabriel to the Virgin Mary, announcing the birth of Jesus.
ref_descr: Words seen in a wall carving depicting the Annunciation.

name: Ave Maria
description: Prayer to the Virgin Mary.
ref_descr: Sung by Piccarda in the Heaven of the Moon.

name: Averroes (1126–1198)
description: Andalusian-Arab philosopher, physician, and famous commentator ("il gran comento") on Aristotle.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Avicenna (980–1037)
description: Persian physician, philosopher, and scientist. He wrote commentaries on Aristotle and Galen.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Azzo VIII
description: Lord of Ferrara, Modena and Reggio from 1293 until his death in 1308. He was rumoured to have murdered his father Obizzo II d'Este.
ref_descr: The "figliastro" who killed Obizzo.

name: Bacchus
description: The Roman name of the Greek god Dionysus, protector of wine.
ref_descr: Born in the Thebes.

name: Barrators
description: Those who have committed the sin of barratry.
ref_descr: The barrators, are found in the fifth pouch in a lake of boiling pitch guarded by the Malebranche.

name: Barratry
description: The sin of selling or paying for offices or positions in the public service or officialdom (cf. simony).
ref_descr: One of the sins of ordinary fraud punished in the eighth circle.

name: "Beati misericordes"
description: "Blessed are the merciful." (Mat 5:7)
ref_descr: Heard by Dante as he passed upward out of the terrace of the envious.

name: "Beati mundo corde"
description: "Blessed are the pure in heart." (Mat 5:8).
ref_descr: Sung by an angel before Dante passed upward out of the terrace of the lustful.

name: "Beati pacifici"
description: "Blessed are peacemakers." (Mat 5:9)
ref_descr: Heard by Dante as he passed upward out of the terrace of the angry.

name: "Beati pauperes spiritu"
description: "Blessed are the poor in spirit." (Mat 5:3)
ref_descr: Heard by Dante as he passed upward out of the terrace of the prideful.

name: "Beati quorum tecta sunt peccata"
description: "Blessed are they whose sins are covered." (Psalm 32:1; Psalm 31:1 in the Latin Vulgate.)
ref_descr: Sung by Matilda as she conversed with Dante in Terrestrial Paradise.

name: Beatrice (1266–1290)
description: Dante's idealised childhood love, Beatrice Portinari. In the poem, she awaits the poet in Paradise, replaces Virgil as Dante's guide, and conducts him through the heavens. She symbolises Heavenly Wisdom.
ref_descr: The "worthier spirit" who Virgil says will act as Dante's guide in Paradise.

name: Beatrice (1266–1290)
description: Dante's idealised childhood love, Beatrice Portinari. In the poem, she awaits the poet in Paradise, replaces Virgil as Dante's guide, and conducts him through the heavens. She symbolises Heavenly Wisdom.
ref_descr: Asks Virgil to rescue Dante and bring him on his journey.

name: Beatrice (1266–1290)
description: Dante's idealised childhood love, Beatrice Portinari. In the poem, she awaits the poet in Paradise, replaces Virgil as Dante's guide, and conducts him through the heavens. She symbolises Heavenly Wisdom.
ref_descr: Asked by Lucia to help Dante.

name: Beatrice (1266–1290)
description: Dante's idealised childhood love, Beatrice Portinari. In the poem, she awaits the poet in Paradise, replaces Virgil as Dante's guide, and conducts him through the heavens. She symbolises Heavenly Wisdom.
ref_descr: When Dante appears upset by Farinata's prophecy on his future exile, Virgil intervenes and explains to him that Beatrice, "quella il cui bell' occhio tutto vede" ("one whose gracious eyes see everything"), will eventually clarify all.

name: Beatrice (1266–1290)
description: Dante's idealised childhood love, Beatrice Portinari. In the poem, she awaits the poet in Paradise, replaces Virgil as Dante's guide, and conducts him through the heavens. She symbolises Heavenly Wisdom.
ref_descr: Virgil, speaking with Chiron, alludes to Beatrice as she who has entrusted Dante to him.

name: Beatrice (1266–1290)
description: Dante's idealised childhood love, Beatrice Portinari. In the poem, she awaits the poet in Paradise, replaces Virgil as Dante's guide, and conducts him through the heavens. She symbolises Heavenly Wisdom.
ref_descr: Speaking with Brunetto Latini Dante alludes to her as the woman who shall fully explain the sense of Brunetto's prophecy regarding his exile from Florence.

name: Beatrice (1266–1290)
description: Dante's idealised childhood love, Beatrice Portinari. In the poem, she awaits the poet in Paradise, replaces Virgil as Dante's guide, and conducts him through the heavens. She symbolises Heavenly Wisdom.
ref_descr: Virgil uses the promise of meeting Beatrice to encourage Dante to enter the fire of Purgatory.

name: Beatrice (1266–1290)
description: Dante's idealised childhood love, Beatrice Portinari. In the poem, she awaits the poet in Paradise, replaces Virgil as Dante's guide, and conducts him through the heavens. She symbolises Heavenly Wisdom.
ref_descr: Dante meets Beatrice in Purgatory.

name: Saint Bede
description: English monk, and scholar, whose best-known work, Historia ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum (The Ecclesiastical History of the English People) gained him the title "The father of English history".
ref_descr: Encountered in the Fourth Sphere of Heaven (The sun).

name: Belacqua
description: Personal acquaintance of Dante's, perhaps Duccio di Bonavia, a music instrument maker noted for his laziness.
ref_descr: Dante encounters him in Ante-Purgatory, waiting a lifetime because he waited to his deathbed to repent.

name: Belisarius
description: (c. 500–565) Roman general who served under the Emperor Justinian and regained much of Italy for the Empire.
ref_descr: Commended by the soul of Justinian in Heaven.

name: "Benedictus qui venis" ("Blessed are you who come") Variation of "Benedictus qui venit" ("Blessed is he who comes"), sung in the Sanctus of the Latin Mass. The phrase comes from the Gospel of Mark (Mark 11
description: 10), when the crowds welcome Jesus into Jerusalem.
ref_descr: Sung by angels in the Pageant of the Church Triumphant, welcoming Beatrice to the procession.

name: Mastro Benvenuto
description: Nicknamed Asdente ("toothless"), he was a late 13th-century Parma shoemaker, famous for his prophecies against Frederick II. Dante also mentions him with contempt in his Convivio, as does Salimbene in his Cronica, though with a very different tone.
ref_descr: Among the soothsayers.

name: Saint Bernard of Clairvaux
description: 12th-century abbot, mystic, co-founder of the Knights Templar, and a major leader in the reformation of the Benedictine Order through the nascent Cistercian Order.
ref_descr: Guides Dante as he travels through the Empyrean.

name: Gualdrada Berti
description: Daughter of Bellincione Berti dei Ravignani, from about 1180 wife to Guido the Elder of the great Guidi family, and grandmother of Guido Guerra. The 14th-century Florentine chronicler Giovanni Villani remembers her as a model of ancient Florentine virtue.
ref_descr: "The good Gualdrada".

name: Bertran de Born (c. 1140 – c. 1215)
description: French soldier and troubadour poet, and viscount of Hautefort, he fomented trouble between Henry II of England and his sons.
ref_descr: Among the sowers of discord, where he carries his severed head (although he died a natural death).

name: Bertran de Born (c. 1140 – c. 1215)
description: French soldier and troubadour poet, and viscount of Hautefort, he fomented trouble between Henry II of England and his sons.
ref_descr: "The lord of Hautefort."

name: Guido Bonatti
description: A prominent 13th-century astrologer, and a staunch Ghibelline, he is famous for having boasted of being responsible for the Senese victory at Montaperti in 1260.
ref_descr: Among the soothsayers.

name: Bonaventure
description: Franciscan theologian.
ref_descr: He eulogised St. Dominic.

name: Buonconte
description: Son of military strategist Guido da Montefeltro, he helped expel the Guelph party from Arezzo in 1287. His army was defeated by Guelphs from Florence at the Battle of Campaldino in 1289. Dante fought for Florence in the battle. Buonconte's body was not found after the battle.
ref_descr: Dante encounters Buonconte waiting to enter Purgatory among the souls who died violent deaths and repented in the final moments.

name: Pope Boniface VIII (c. 1235–1303)
description: Elected in 1294 upon the abdication of Celestine V, whom he promptly imprisoned. He supported the Black Guelphs against Dante's party the White Guelphs (see Guelphs and Ghibellines). He was in conflict with the powerful Colonna family, who contested the legitimacy of Celestine's abdication, and thus Boniface's papacy. Wishing to capture the impregnable Colonna stronghold of Palestrina, he sought advice from Guido da Montefeltro, offering in advance papal absolution for any sin his advice might entail. He advised Boniface to promise the Colonnas amnesty, then break it. As a result, the Collonas surrendered the fortress and it was razed to the ground.
ref_descr: "One who tacks his sails".

ref_descr: Referred to ironically using one of the official papal titles "servo de' servi" (Servant of His servants").

ref_descr: Accused of avarice, deceit and violating the "lovely Lady" (the church).

ref_descr: Pope Nicholas III prophesies his eternal damnation among the Simoniacs.

ref_descr: The "highest priest—may he be damned!".

ref_descr: The "prince of the new Pharisees".

ref_descr: His feud with the Colonna family and the advice of Guido da Montefeltro.

ref_descr: Treatment at the hands of Philip IV of France compared to a new crucifixion of Jesus.
