ref_descr: A sodomite mentioned in the seventh circle, round 3 by Jacopo Rusticucci as having spoken to him and his companions of the moral decline of Florence, generating great anguish and inducing Rusticucci to ask Dante for corroboration.

name: Martin Bottario
description: A cooper of Lucca who held various positions in the government of his city. He died in 1300, the year of Dante's travel.
ref_descr: Probably the "elder of Saint Zita" who is plunged into a lake of boiling pitch with the other barrators by a Malebranche.

name: Brennus
description: Gaulic king who invaded Rome and held the city for ransom in the 4th century BCE.
ref_descr: He was the last successful foreign invader of the city until the 5th century.

name: Briareus
description: Son of Uranus and Gaia and one of the Hekatonkheires ("hundred-handed")
ref_descr: Bound in the Well of the Giants in Hell. Dante asks Virgil to point him out.

name: Briareus
description: Son of Uranus and Gaia and one of the Hekatonkheires ("hundred-handed")
ref_descr: Depicted on the pavement in Purgatory being hurled from Olympus as an exemplar of arrogance.

name: Agnello Brunelleschi
description: From the noble Florentine Brunelleschi family, he sided first with the White Guelphs, then the Blacks. A famous thief, he was said to steal in disguise.
ref_descr: Among the thieves, he merges with Cianfa Donati to form a bigger serpent.

name: Brutus, Lucius Junius
description: Traditionally viewed as the founder of the Roman Republic, because of his role in overthrowing Tarquin, the last Roman king.
ref_descr: Seen in Limbo.

name: Cacciaguida
description: Italian crusader and the great-great-grandfather of Dante Alighieri.
ref_descr: Among the Warriors of the Faith in the fifth sphere of heaven.

name: Venedico and Ghisolabella Caccianemico
description: Venedico (c. 1228 – c. 1302) was head of the Guelph faction in Bologna, he was exiled three times for his relationship with the marquess of Ferrara, Obizzo II d'Este.
ref_descr: Found among the panders, he confesses that he prostituted his sister Ghisolabella to Obizzo.

name: Cacus
description: A mythological monster son of Hephaestus, he was killed by Heracles for stealing part of the cattle the hero had taken from Geryon. Dante, like other medieval writers, erroneously believes him to be a Centaur. According to Virgil he lived on the Aventine.
ref_descr: As guardian of the thieves he punishes Vanni Fucci.

name: Cadmus
description: Mythical son of the Phoenician king Agenor and brother of Europa, and legendary founder of Thebes. Cadmus and his wife Harmonia are ultimately transformed into serpents. (See also Hera.)
ref_descr: His transformation in Ovid's Metamophoses (IV, 562–603) is compared to the fate of the thieves.

name: Caecilius
description: Roman poet of the 2nd century BCE.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Cahors
description: Town in France that was notorious for its Cahorsins, Christian financiers who engaged in usury that was then considered sinful.
ref_descr: Mentioned as being punished in the last circle.

name: A popular tradition identified the Moon's dark spots as the marks on Cain's face mentioned in Genesis 4
ref_descr: The outermost ring of Cocytus, where the treacherous to kin are punished, is named Caïna.

name: Caiaphas
description: The Jewish High Priest during the governorship of Pontius Pilate of the Roman province of Judea, who according to the Gospels had an important role in the crucifixion of Jesus.
ref_descr: Among the hypocrites, his punishment is to be crucified to the ground while the full rank of the sinners tramples him.

name: Calchas
description: Mythical Greek seer at the time of the Trojan war, who as augur at Aulis, determined the most propitious time for the Greek fleet to depart for Troy.
ref_descr: With Eurypylus, he "set the time to cut the cables".

name: Calliope
description: The Muse of epic poetry.
ref_descr: Invoked by Dante at the beginning of the Purgatorio.

name: Camilla
description: Figure from Roman mythology and Virgil's Aeneid (VII, 803; XI), was the warrior-daughter of King Metabus of the Volsci, and ally of Turnus, king of the Rutuli, against Aeneas and the Trojans, and was killed in that war.
ref_descr: One of those who "died for Italy".

name: Camilla
description: Figure from Roman mythology and Virgil's Aeneid (VII, 803; XI), was the warrior-daughter of King Metabus of the Volsci, and ally of Turnus, king of the Rutuli, against Aeneas and the Trojans, and was killed in that war.
ref_descr: Seen in Limbo.

name: Capaneus
description: In Greek mythology, in the war of the Seven against Thebes, he defied Zeus who then killed him with a thunderbolt in punishment.
ref_descr: Found amongst the violent against God.

name: Capaneus
description: In Greek mythology, in the war of the Seven against Thebes, he defied Zeus who then killed him with a thunderbolt in punishment.
ref_descr: His pride is compared with that of Vanni Fucci.

name: Capocchio
description: Burned at the stake for alchemy in 1293.
ref_descr: Among the "falsifiers" of metal (alchemists), sitting with Griffolino of Arezzo, propping each other up, as they frantically scratch at the scabs covering their bodies.

name: Capocchio
description: Burned at the stake for alchemy in 1293.
ref_descr: Agrees with Dante about the vanity of the Sienese, giving as examples four of the members of the Sienese Spendthrift Club, then identifies himself.

name: Capocchio
description: Burned at the stake for alchemy in 1293.
ref_descr: He is dragged, with his belly scraped along the ground, by the tusks of Schicchi.

name: Caprona
description: Fortress on the Arno near Pisa, in 1289, it was besieged by a Tuscan Guelph army. The Ghibellines surrendered, and were allowed, under truce, to leave the castle, passing through (with trepidation) the enemy ranks. Caprona's fall along with the Guelph victory in the same year at Campaldino represented the final defeat of the Ghibellines. Dante's reference to Caprona in the Inferno, is used to infer that he took part in the siege.
ref_descr: Dante's fear for his safe passage through threatening devils, is compared to the fear of the surrendering soldiers at Caprona.

name: Cardinal Virtues
description: The foundations of a moral life, attainable by all, regardless of religion. They include Prudence, Temperance, Justice, and Fortitude.
ref_descr: They appear symbolically as four stars visible from Purgatory.

name: Cardinal Virtues
description: The foundations of a moral life, attainable by all, regardless of religion. They include Prudence, Temperance, Justice, and Fortitude.
ref_descr: Virgil defines Prudence as "the power that counsels and keeps the threshold of assent."

name: Cassius
description: The most senior of Julius Caesar's assassins, Gaius Cassius Longinus was a Roman politician and soldier.
ref_descr: Along with Brutus and Judas, he was one of the three betrayer/suicides who, for those sins, were eternally chewed by one of the three mouths of Satan.

name: Catalano dei Malavolti (c. 1210–1285)
description: From a powerful Guelph family of Bologna, he was podestà in several towns, including Florence, and governor of his city. He was commander of the infantry in the Battle of Fossalta in 1249, when the Ghibellines suffered a crushing defeat. He later became a member of the Knights of St. Mary, founded by Loderingo degli Andalò.
ref_descr: Among the hypocrites.

name: Catiline
description: a Roman politician of the 1st century BCE who is best known for the "Catiline conspiracy", an attempt to overthrow the Roman Republic, and in particular the power of the aristocratic Senate.
ref_descr: Probably Pistoia's "seed", which Pistoia surpasses in "wickedness".

name: Cato the Younger (95–46 BCE)
description: Politician and statesman in the late Roman Republic, and a Stoic.
ref_descr: His crossing of the Libyan desert in 47 BCE provides a simile for the hot sands of the seventh circle.

name: Cato the Younger (95–46 BCE)
description: Politician and statesman in the late Roman Republic, and a Stoic.
ref_descr: The "patriarch" who resides at the base of Mount Purgatory and functions as gate-keeper for Purgatory.

name: Francesco de' Cavalcanti
description: Nicknamed Guercio ("one-eyed" or "squinter"), he was murdered for unknown reasons by the inhabitants of the village of Gaville, near Florence. Reportedly his death started a bloody feud between his family and the villagers, leaving most of the inhabitants of Galville dead.
ref_descr: Among the thieves, as a "blazing little serpent", he attacks the soul of Buoso Donati, causing it to transform into a serpent, and himself to transform back into human form.

name: Pope Celestine V
description: A hermit named Pietro da Morrone, he abdicated the Papacy in 1294 after only five months. His successor, Boniface VIII, immediately jailed him and two years later apparently murdered him.
ref_descr: Is perhaps the person whose shade Dante meets in the Ante-Inferno, where those who lived "sanza 'nfamia e sanza lodo" (without praise and blame) dwelt, and referred to as the one, "Che fece per viltate il gran rifiuto" (who made, through cowardice, the great refusal).

name: Pope Celestine V
description: A hermit named Pietro da Morrone, he abdicated the Papacy in 1294 after only five months. His successor, Boniface VIII, immediately jailed him and two years later apparently murdered him.
ref_descr: Of whom Boniface says, "I possess the power to lock and unlock Heaven; for the keys my predecessor did not prise are two". '

name: Centaurs
description: In Greek mythology, a race part Man and part horse, with a horse's body and a human head and torso.
ref_descr: Supervising the punishment of the violent. Their leader Chiron appoints one of their number, Nessus, to guide the poets.

name: Centaurs
description: In Greek mythology, a race part Man and part horse, with a horse's body and a human head and torso.
ref_descr: The only one not with the violent is Cacus, who supervises the thieves.

name: Centaurs
description: In Greek mythology, a race part Man and part horse, with a horse's body and a human head and torso.
ref_descr: Cited as examples of gluttony in Purgatory by a voice hidden in a tree of temptation, because of their drunken behavior at the marriage feast of Hippodamia.

name: Cerberus
description: In Greek mythology, he was the three-headed dog who guarded the gate to Hades. In the Aeneid, Virgil has the Sibyl throw a drugged honey cake into Cerberus' mouths; in the Inferno, Dante has Virgil throw dirt instead.
ref_descr: Encountered In the third circle.

name: Cerberus
description: In Greek mythology, he was the three-headed dog who guarded the gate to Hades. In the Aeneid, Virgil has the Sibyl throw a drugged honey cake into Cerberus' mouths; in the Inferno, Dante has Virgil throw dirt instead.
ref_descr: Example of divine punishment.

name: Charles the Lame
description: Son of Charles of Anjou and King of Naples (1285–1309)
ref_descr: Forced to marry off his daughters "like slaves" for political alliances.

name: Charles of Anjou (also Charles I of Sicily) (1227–1285)
description: Son of Louis VIII of France, he was one of the most powerful rulers of his age and the undisputed head of the Guelph faction in Italy. His dream of building a Mediterranean Empire was wrecked by the Sicilian Vespers.
ref_descr: Dante probably alludes to the Byzantine money that it was believed Nicholas III had taken with the promise to hinder Charles' plans against Constantinople.

name: Charles of Anjou (also Charles I of Sicily) (1227–1285)
description: Son of Louis VIII of France, he was one of the most powerful rulers of his age and the undisputed head of the Guelph faction in Italy. His dream of building a Mediterranean Empire was wrecked by the Sicilian Vespers.
ref_descr: Defeated Conradin at Tagliacozzo in 1268 and became King of Sicily.

name: Charles of Anjou (also Charles I of Sicily) (1227–1285)
description: Son of Louis VIII of France, he was one of the most powerful rulers of his age and the undisputed head of the Guelph faction in Italy. His dream of building a Mediterranean Empire was wrecked by the Sicilian Vespers.
ref_descr: According to Dante, responsible for the death of Thomas Aquinas.

name: Charles of Valois
description: (1270–1325) Second son of Philip III of France. Invaded Italy and took Florence in 1301, placing the Black Guelphs in power. Subsequently, Dante was exiled from Florence.
ref_descr: Compared to Judas.

name: Charybdis
description: In Greek mythology, a sea monster who swallows huge amounts of water three times a day and then spouts it back out again, forming an enormous whirlpool. Mentioned frequently by classical writers.
ref_descr: Used in a simile to describe the punishment of the greedy and prodigal in the fourth circle.

name: Ciacco ("pig")
description: Nickname, for a Florentine contemporary of Dante, perhaps well known as a glutton, and probably the same who appears in Boccaccio's Decameron (IX, 8).
ref_descr: Central figure of canto VI, he voices the first of many prophecies concerning Florence.

name: Ciampolo di Navarra
description: Utterly unknown to sources other than Dante, this Ciampolo (i.e. Jean Paul) appears to have been in the service of Theobald II, king of Navarre.
ref_descr: Among the barrators.

name: Cianghella della Tosa
description: 14th-century Florentian woman. She was born into the Florentine Della Tosa family and married into the Alidosi family of Imola, near Bologna.
ref_descr: Listed as an example of the corrupt nature of Florentine citizens in his time, in contrast to the virtue of the idealized Florence in Cacciaguida's time.

name: Cicero, Marcus Tullius (c. 106 – c. 43 BCE)
description: Roman statesman and author.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Cimabue
description: Florentine painter (c. 1240–1302)
ref_descr: Mentioned in Purgatory as a famous painter.

name: Circe
description: Mythical daughter of Helios, god of the Sun, and sister of Aeetis, king of Colchis. She was an enchantress who lived near the Gulf of Gaeta, who turned the crew of Odysseus into pigs on their journey home from the Trojan war. But Odysseus, with the help of Hermes, forced her to release his men from her spell (Ovid, Met. XIV, 435–440). She fell in love with Odysseus and he stayed with her for another year and in some accounts, she had a son Telegonus with Odysseus, who was to accidentally kill him.
ref_descr: It is said, by Ulysses (Odysseus), that she "beguiled" him.

name: Circe
description: Mythical daughter of Helios, god of the Sun, and sister of Aeetis, king of Colchis. She was an enchantress who lived near the Gulf of Gaeta, who turned the crew of Odysseus into pigs on their journey home from the Trojan war. But Odysseus, with the help of Hermes, forced her to release his men from her spell (Ovid, Met. XIV, 435–440). She fell in love with Odysseus and he stayed with her for another year and in some accounts, she had a son Telegonus with Odysseus, who was to accidentally kill him.
ref_descr: The people of Tuscany fall into vice, as if under her spell.

name: Pope Clement V (1264–1314)
description: Born in France as Bertran de Goth, he was made archbishop of Bordeaux by Pope Boniface VIII. He was elected pope in 1305 and was remarkable for his dissolution of the Templars and his de facto move of the Papal See from Rome to Avignon (See Avignon Papacy). He was thought to have negotiated with Philip IV of France for his papacy, becoming a puppet of the French monarchy.
ref_descr: "One uglier in deeds ... a lawless shepherd from the west", whose damnation among the Simoniacs is foretold by Pope Nicholas III.

name: Cleopatra (69–30 BCE)
description: Queen of Egypt, lover of Julius Caesar and Mark Antony. Like Dido, she "killed herself for love".
ref_descr: Found amongst the sexual sinners.

name: Clio
description: The Muse of History.
ref_descr: Mentioned by Virgil as Statius' inspiration in writing the Thebaid.

name: Clotho
description: The Fate who determines the lifespan of each mortal by measuring out thread and then cutting it.
ref_descr: Virgil cites her as the reason Dante is yet alive.

name: Cluny
description: A Benedictine monastery founded in 909, in Burgundy. The elegant robes of the Cluniacs are described with irony in a letter of Saint Bernard, a Cistercian, to his nephew Robert, who had left the Cistercians to join the Cluniacs.
ref_descr: The "cloaks and cowls" of the hypocrites are compared to the Cluniac robes.

name: Cocytus
description: "The river of lamentation", in Greek mythology, it was the river on whose banks the dead who could not pay Charon wandered. It flowed into the river Acheron, across which lay Hades. In the Inferno it is a frozen lake forming the ninth circle and the bottom of Hell.
ref_descr: Formed from the tears of the statue of the Old Man of Crete.

name: Cocytus
description: "The river of lamentation", in Greek mythology, it was the river on whose banks the dead who could not pay Charon wandered. It flowed into the river Acheron, across which lay Hades. In the Inferno it is a frozen lake forming the ninth circle and the bottom of Hell.
ref_descr: Is shut in by cold.

name: Cocytus
description: "The river of lamentation", in Greek mythology, it was the river on whose banks the dead who could not pay Charon wandered. It flowed into the river Acheron, across which lay Hades. In the Inferno it is a frozen lake forming the ninth circle and the bottom of Hell.
ref_descr: Described.

name: Cocytus
description: "The river of lamentation", in Greek mythology, it was the river on whose banks the dead who could not pay Charon wandered. It flowed into the river Acheron, across which lay Hades. In the Inferno it is a frozen lake forming the ninth circle and the bottom of Hell.
ref_descr: Frozen by flapping of the wings of Dis.

name: Colchis
description: Ancient kingdom at the eastern end of the Black Sea. According to ancient Greek legend, Jason and the Argonauts sailed there in search of the Golden Fleece.
ref_descr: Dante compares the voyage to his journey through the heavens.

name: Constance (Constanza)
description: Queen of Sicily in the 12th century and mother of Emperor Frederick II.
ref_descr: Dante accepts a story that Constance had taken monastic vows and was later forced to renounce them. She appears among the inconstant in the Heaven of the Moon.

name: Constantine the Great (272–337)
description: The famous Roman Emperor who passed the Edict of Milan in 313 and converted to Christianity. According to medieval legend, Constantine was inflicted with leprosy because of his persecution of Christians, and in a dream was told to seek out Pope Silvester on Mount Soracte, who baptised and cured him. According to the forged document, the Donation of Constantine, Constantine gave to the Pope the power to rule over Rome and the Western Roman Empire, which Dante sees as the source of the corruption of the Papacy.
ref_descr: Blamed for "the dower that you bestowed upon the first rich father!",

name: Constantine the Great (272–337)
description: The famous Roman Emperor who passed the Edict of Milan in 313 and converted to Christianity. According to medieval legend, Constantine was inflicted with leprosy because of his persecution of Christians, and in a dream was told to seek out Pope Silvester on Mount Soracte, who baptised and cured him. According to the forged document, the Donation of Constantine, Constantine gave to the Pope the power to rule over Rome and the Western Roman Empire, which Dante sees as the source of the corruption of the Papacy.
ref_descr: Guido da Montefeltro compares Silvester being sought by Constantine to cure his leprosy, with himself being sought by Boniface to "ease the fever of his arrogance".

name: Constantine the Great (272–337)
description: The famous Roman Emperor who passed the Edict of Milan in 313 and converted to Christianity. According to medieval legend, Constantine was inflicted with leprosy because of his persecution of Christians, and in a dream was told to seek out Pope Silvester on Mount Soracte, who baptised and cured him. According to the forged document, the Donation of Constantine, Constantine gave to the Pope the power to rule over Rome and the Western Roman Empire, which Dante sees as the source of the corruption of the Papacy.
ref_descr: In converting to Christianity, Constantine reversed the flight of the Roman Eagle.

name: Cornelia Africana (c. 190–100 BCE)
description: daughter of Scipio Africanus Major, and mother of Tiberius and Gaius Gracchus.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Cronus
description: In Greek mythology, King of Crete during the Golden Age. He had several children by Rhea, but swallowed them at birth because he had learned from his parents Gaia and Uranus, that he was destined to be overthrown by a son. However, Rhea managed to save Zeus who eventually fulfilled that prophecy.
ref_descr: Under his rule, the world lived chastely".

name: Cronus
description: In Greek mythology, King of Crete during the Golden Age. He had several children by Rhea, but swallowed them at birth because he had learned from his parents Gaia and Uranus, that he was destined to be overthrown by a son. However, Rhea managed to save Zeus who eventually fulfilled that prophecy.
ref_descr: Rhea protects Zeus from him.

name: Gaius Scribonius Curio
description: A distinguished orator, and supporter of Pompey the Great, he switched his support to Julius Caesar after Caesar paid his debts. Lucan (Phars I 270–290) has Curio urge Caesar persuasively, to quickly cross the Rubicon and invade Rome.
ref_descr: Among the sowers of discord, he is pointed out by Pier da Medincina, his tongue having been slit, "who once was so audacious in his talk!".

name: Cyclops
description: Children of Uranus and Gaia, they were giants with a single eye in the middle of their forehead. In Roman mythology, they helped Vulcan make thunderbolts for Zeus.
ref_descr: The "others" who Zeus "may tire" making thunderbolts.

name: Cytherea
description: Alternative name for Aphrodite or Venus, the goddess of love. Also, the planet Venus.
ref_descr: In his last night in Purgatory, Dante dreams as the planet is rising.

name: Daedalus
description: In Greek mythology, he was a legendary inventor and craftsman. He designed the Labyrinth, and fashioned wings for himself and his son Icarus, enabling them to fly.
ref_descr: Mentioned by Griffolino of Arezzo.

name: Daniel
description: Protagonist in the Book of Daniel of the Hebrew Bible. He and his companions fasted rather than incur ritual defilement when they ate in the court of the king of Babylon.
ref_descr: A voice in Purgatory cites Daniel as an example in the virtue of temperance.

name: Daniel
description: Protagonist in the Book of Daniel of the Hebrew Bible. He and his companions fasted rather than incur ritual defilement when they ate in the court of the king of Babylon.
ref_descr: Dante compares Beatrice's solution of his mental doubts to Daniel's solution of Nebuchadnezzar's troubled dream in the biblical book of Daniel.

name: Danube
description: European river flowing through much of central and southeastern Europe.
ref_descr: Cocytus is compared to the Danube when frozen during the wintertime.

name: Bonturo Dati (died 1324)
description: Head of the popular faction in Lucca, he expelled his enemies in 1308 assuming the government of the city, boasting he would put an end to barratry. He is famous for provoking with his jeers in 1313 a war with Pisa, that has been remembered in Faida di Comune by Giosuè Carducci.
ref_descr: Sarcastically and ironically said that all Luccans but he are guilty of barratry.

name: King David
description: Biblical king of the Jews. His counselor Ahithophel, incited David's son Absalom against him.
ref_descr: Raised by Jesus from Limbo into Paradise.

name: King David
description: Biblical king of the Jews. His counselor Ahithophel, incited David's son Absalom against him.
ref_descr: His son's rebellion, and the urgings of Ahithophel is compared by Bertran de Born to his own urgings of Prince Henry against his father Henry II of England.

name: King David
description: Biblical king of the Jews. His counselor Ahithophel, incited David's son Absalom against him.
ref_descr: Appears depicted in a wall carving as the "humble psalmist," leading the procession of the Ark to Jerusalem.

name: Decii
description: Three generations of men in a Patrician Roman family, who each answered the call to arms and died in battle.
ref_descr: Mentioned as exemplars of Roman virtue in the days of the Roman Republic.

name: Deidamia
description: Mythical daughter of Lycomedes, king of Scyros, she gave birth to Achilles' only son, Pyrrhus Neoptolemus, but died of grief when, because of the urgings of Odysseus (Ulysses), Achilles left her to go to the war against Troy.
ref_descr: Even dead she laments Achilles still.

name: Deidamia
description: Mythical daughter of Lycomedes, king of Scyros, she gave birth to Achilles' only son, Pyrrhus Neoptolemus, but died of grief when, because of the urgings of Odysseus (Ulysses), Achilles left her to go to the war against Troy.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Deipyle
description: Ancient Greek wife of Tydeus and mother of Diomedes.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: "Delectasti"
description: ("Quia delectasti me, Domine, in factura tua": "For thou hast given me, O Lord, a delight in thy doings.") Psalm 92:5 (91:5 in the Latin Vulgate)
ref_descr: Quoted by Matilda as the reason she smiled broadly at Dante in Terrestrial Paradise.

name: Democritus (c. 460–370 BCE)
description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo, "che 'l mondo a caso pone" ("who ascribes the world to chance").

name: "Deus, venerunt gentes"
description: ("O God, the heathen have come.") Incipit of Psalm 79 (Psalm 78 in the Vulgate)
ref_descr: Chanted as a lamentation over the Church by the women representing the Three Theological Virtues and Cardinal Virtues.

name: Diana
description: Greco-Roman goddess, known as the "virgin goddess."
ref_descr: Cited as an example of sexual abstinence by souls on the terrace of the lustful.

name: Diogenes of Sinope (c. 412–323 BCE)
description: Greek philosopher.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Diomedes
description: Mythical king of Argus, he participated in the expedition against Troy, where his prowess is extolled in the Iliad. A great friend of Odysseus (Ulysses), he was his companion in many feats, most notably the theft of Troy's Palladium and the ruse of the Trojan Horse.
ref_descr: Among the advisors of fraud, he is punished with Ulysses for the sins they both committed at Troy.

name: Dionysius the Areopagite (fl. c. 50)
description: Athenian judge who was converted to Christianity and became a bishop of Athens. As was common in the Middle Ages, Dante has confused him with Pseudo-Dionysius, the anonymous 5th-century author of Celestial Hierarchy.
ref_descr: Identified in the Heaven of the Sun by Thomas Aquinas.

name: Dionysius the Elder
description: Tyrant of Syracuse (405–367 BCE).
ref_descr: Pointed out by Nessus.

name: Pedanius Dioscorides (c. 40 – c. 90)
description: Greek physician and author of a work on the medicinal properties of plants, hence Dante's description of him as "il buono accoglitor del quale"/"the good collector of the qualities".
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Dis
description: Another name for Pluto, the Roman god of the underworld, used by Dante as both the name of Satan and his realm.
ref_descr: First glimpse of the "crimson" city.

name: Dis
description: Another name for Pluto, the Roman god of the underworld, used by Dante as both the name of Satan and his realm.
ref_descr: Dante refused entry.

name: Dis
description: Another name for Pluto, the Roman god of the underworld, used by Dante as both the name of Satan and his realm.
ref_descr: The city dolente (of sorrowing).

name: Dis
description: Another name for Pluto, the Roman god of the underworld, used by Dante as both the name of Satan and his realm.
ref_descr: Entrance.

name: Dis
description: Another name for Pluto, the Roman god of the underworld, used by Dante as both the name of Satan and his realm.
ref_descr: Spoils taken from by Jesus.

name: Dis
description: Another name for Pluto, the Roman god of the underworld, used by Dante as both the name of Satan and his realm.
ref_descr: Pointed out by Virgil.

name: Saint Dominic
description: Founder of the Dominican Order.
ref_descr: He is eulogised by Bonaventure.

name: Domitian
description: Roman Emperor (81–96). His religious policies resulted in persecution of Christians and Jews.
ref_descr: Statius relates how witnessing the persecution helped to convert him to Christianity.

name: Buoso Donati
description: Of the noble Florentine Black Guelph Donati family, he was one of those who accepted the peace between the factions proposed by Cardinal Latino in 1280. He died around 1285.
ref_descr: Among the thieves, he is transformed into a serpent by Francesco de' Cavalcanti.

name: Buoso Donati
description: Of the noble Florentine Black Guelph Donati family, he was one of those who accepted the peace between the factions proposed by Cardinal Latino in 1280. He died around 1285.
ref_descr: His impersonation by Gianni Schicchi described.

name: Cianfa Donati
description: Of the Donati family, he is known to have acted as advisor to the Capitano del popolo in 1281. In 1289 he is reported as already dead.
ref_descr: Among the thieves, he appears as a six-footed serpent, attacks and melds with Agnello Brunelleschi.

name: Forese Donati (?–1296)
description: A Florentine poet, friend of Dante, and relative of Dante's wife, Gemma Alighieri.
ref_descr: Among the gluttons, he predicts disaster for Florence and for his brother, Corso Donati.

name: Forese Donati (?–1296)
description: A Florentine poet, friend of Dante, and relative of Dante's wife, Gemma Alighieri.
ref_descr: Notes that the prayers of his surviving wife Nella have greatly reduced his stay in Purgatory.

name: Piccarda Donati
description: Sister of Forese Donanti, already dead at the time setting of the Comedy.
ref_descr: In Purgatory, Dante asks Forese Donati where his dead sister is and learns that she is "in triumph."

name: Piccarda Donati
description: Sister of Forese Donanti, already dead at the time setting of the Comedy.
ref_descr: Allegorical representation of the Islamic conquests of Christian territory in the Pageant of Church History.

name: Eagle
description: Bird which appeared on the Standard of the Roman Legions and symbolized the authority of the empire.
ref_descr: An Eagle appears twice in the Pageant of Church History. It first represents the persecution of the early Church by the Roman Empire.

name: Eagle
description: Bird which appeared on the Standard of the Roman Legions and symbolized the authority of the empire.
ref_descr: Then it returns, representing connection of the Church and Empire starting with the Emperor Constantine I.

name: Eagle
description: Bird which appeared on the Standard of the Roman Legions and symbolized the authority of the empire.
ref_descr: The administration of justice is dispensed in the form of an Eagle

name: Eagle
description: Bird which appeared on the Standard of the Roman Legions and symbolized the authority of the empire.
ref_descr: and answers Dante in Par. XIX and Par. XX on the matter of whether any who are not Christian can be saved.

name: Ebro
description: River in Spain.
ref_descr: Used as a reference to the time of day. Dante considered it to be 6 hours ahead of Purgatory.

name: Ecce ancilla Dei
description: "Behold the handmaid of God." (In the original Vulgate: "Ecce ancilla Domini.") Response of the Virgin Mary to the angel Gabriel when he announced that she would be the mother of Jesus.
ref_descr: Words seen in a wall-carving depicting the Annunciation. It is a visual representation of humility.

name: Electra
description: Mother of Dardanus founder of Troy and ancestor of Aeneas.
ref_descr: Seen in Limbo with "her many comrades".

name: Elijah and Elisha
description: Elijah was an Old Testament Biblical Prophet who ascends into heaven in a chariot of fire, and Elisha was his disciple and chosen successor who witnessed Elijah's ascent. Elisha curses some youths for ridiculing him, who are then eaten by bears (2 Kings 2:23–24; 11–12)
ref_descr: Elijah's fiery ascent, as witnessed by "he who was avenged by bears" (Elisha), is described.

name: Empedocles (c. 490 – c. 430 BCE)
description: Greek Presocratic philosopher.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Ephialtes
description: Son of Poseidon and Iphimedeia, Ephialtes was a giant who attempted to scale Mt. Olympus by piling mountains on each other.
ref_descr: Seen chained in the "Well of the Giants."

name: Ephialtes
description: Son of Poseidon and Iphimedeia, Ephialtes was a giant who attempted to scale Mt. Olympus by piling mountains on each other.
ref_descr: Epicurean heretics and their punishment.

name: Erichtho
description: According to a story in Lucan's Pharsalia, she was a sorceress sent to the underworld by Sextus Pompeius to divine the outcome of the upcoming battle of Pharsalia between his father, Pompey the Great, and Julius Caesar.
ref_descr: She sent Virgil to the innermost circle of hell not long after his death.

name: Erinyes
description: (also known as the Furies). In Greek mythology, they were Alecto, Megaera, and Tisiphone, three female personifications of vengeance.
ref_descr: They appear and threaten Dante with the head of the Medusa.

name: Erysichthon
description: Ancient King of Thessaly who cut down a grove of trees sacred to Demeter. Her revenge was to give him insatiable hunger which eventually caused him to consume his own flesh.
ref_descr: Seeing fasting souls in Purgatory on the terrace of the gluttonous, Dante is reminded of Erysichthon's story.

name: Eteocles and Polynices
description: Mythical sons of Oedipus and Jocasta, they succeeded their father as kings of Thebes. Eteocles' refusal to share the throne led to the war of the Seven against Thebes, in which the two brothers killed each other. Their enmity in life was such that Statius (Thebais XII, 429 ff.) says even the flames of their shared funeral pyre were divided.
ref_descr: The separateness of the flames of Ulysses and Diomedes are compared to their funeral flames.

name: Ethiopia
description: empire of the Abyssinian people situated on the Horn of Africa under the Solomonic dynasty (1270-1974).
ref_descr: the Eagle of Justice cites the people of Ethiopia, along with peoples of Persia and India, among examples of those naturally and blamelessly without knowledge of Christ who at the Day of Judgement will, nevertheless, be closer to Christ than many who call themselves Christian,

name: Euclid (c. 365–275 BCE)
description: Greek mathematician, now known as "the father of geometry".
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Eunoe
description: River originating in Terrestrial Paradise which shares a common source with the River Lethe. To drink from the Eunoe is to recall to memory all the good deeds of one's life after losing all memory in the River Lethe.
ref_descr: Not found in classical sources, the Eunoe is a creation of Dante. The word means "good knowledge" in Greek.

name: Euripides
description: Greek playwright of the 5th century BCE.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Eurypylus
description: He was a member of the Greek army that conquered Troy. It is told that while the fleet was at Aulis he was sent to the Delphic Sibyl to ask for a favourable wind.
ref_descr: Seen among the seers, with Calchas, he "set the time to cut the cables".

name: Ezzelino da Romano III (1194–1259)
description: Leader of the Ghibellines in Northern Italy, known for his cruelties against the citizens of Padua.
ref_descr: Pointed out by Nessus.

name: Fabii
description: Roman family of the Republican Age.
ref_descr: Cited as examples of dedication to the public life and to the glory of ancient Rome.

name: Fabricius
description: Caius Fabricius, famous Roman hero of the 3rd century BCE. He is remembered for his frugality and his refusal to accept substantial bribes from Pyrrhus.
ref_descr: Cited by Hugh Capet, who is repenting on the terrace of the greedy, as an example of life without greed.

name: Falterona
description: Mountain in the Apennine Range
ref_descr: Mentioned as the source of the Arno River.

name: Farinata degli Uberti (died 1264)
description: Leader of the Florentine Ghibellines famous for his defeat of the Guelphs (Dante's faction), at the Battle of Montaperti in 1260, causing the Guelphs to be exiled from Florence, though he was able to argue successfully against the destruction of the city. Farinata was posthumously condemned as a heretic during the Franciscan inquisition of 1283. To make peace between the Black and White Guelphs, Cavalcante de' Cavalcanti, let his son Guido Cavalcanti, the future poet, marry Farinata's daughter.
ref_descr: One of a group of famous political Florentines, "who were so worthy ... whose minds bent toward the good", asked about by Dante of Ciacco.

name: Farinata degli Uberti (died 1264)
description: Leader of the Florentine Ghibellines famous for his defeat of the Guelphs (Dante's faction), at the Battle of Montaperti in 1260, causing the Guelphs to be exiled from Florence, though he was able to argue successfully against the destruction of the city. Farinata was posthumously condemned as a heretic during the Franciscan inquisition of 1283. To make peace between the Black and White Guelphs, Cavalcante de' Cavalcanti, let his son Guido Cavalcanti, the future poet, marry Farinata's daughter.
ref_descr: Found among the Epicurean heretics.

name: Farinata degli Uberti (died 1264)
description: Leader of the Florentine Ghibellines famous for his defeat of the Guelphs (Dante's faction), at the Battle of Montaperti in 1260, causing the Guelphs to be exiled from Florence, though he was able to argue successfully against the destruction of the city. Farinata was posthumously condemned as a heretic during the Franciscan inquisition of 1283. To make peace between the Black and White Guelphs, Cavalcante de' Cavalcanti, let his son Guido Cavalcanti, the future poet, marry Farinata's daughter.
ref_descr: Predicts Dante's difficulty in returning to Florence after his exile.

name: Farinata degli Uberti (died 1264)
description: Leader of the Florentine Ghibellines famous for his defeat of the Guelphs (Dante's faction), at the Battle of Montaperti in 1260, causing the Guelphs to be exiled from Florence, though he was able to argue successfully against the destruction of the city. Farinata was posthumously condemned as a heretic during the Franciscan inquisition of 1283. To make peace between the Black and White Guelphs, Cavalcante de' Cavalcanti, let his son Guido Cavalcanti, the future poet, marry Farinata's daughter.
ref_descr: Explains that the damned can see the future but not the present.

name: Florence
description: Dante's home city. He was exiled from Florence in 1302 and never returned. The Comedy was composed during the period of exile.
ref_descr: Condemned with angry sarcasm for its bad government.

name: Folquet de Marseilles (c. 1165–1231)
description: Troubadour, then Cistercian monk, and later Bishop of Toulouse.
ref_descr: Pointed out by Cunizza da Romano.

name: Folquet de Marseilles (c. 1165–1231)
description: Troubadour, then Cistercian monk, and later Bishop of Toulouse.
ref_descr: Speaks to Dante and points out Rahab.

name: Forlì
description: City in Romagna. In 1282, under Guido da Montefeltro, it withstood a combined siege by French and Guelph forces, dealing the French a crushing defeat. After 1300 it was ruled by the Ordelaffi.
ref_descr: "The city that stood long trial".

name: Fortuna major
description: figure formed by a combination of the last stars of Aquarius and the first of Pisces. Used by geomancers for divination.
ref_descr: Visible before dawn in Purgatory.

name: Fox
description: Animal often used to symbolize deceit or cunning.
ref_descr: In the Pageant of Church History, a fox, representing the early Christian heresies, leaps into the Chariot which represents the Church.

name: Francesco d'Accorso
description: Eminent jurist of Bologna who taught law at the universities of Bologna and Oxford. Son of the great Florentine jurist Accorsio da Bagnolo, author of the Glossa Ordinaria on the Corpus Iuris Civilis.
ref_descr: One of a group of sodomites identified by Brunetto Latini to Dante.

name: Saint Francis of Assisi (1182–1226)
description: Son of a wealthy merchant, he spurned his father's riches and founded the Franciscan Order, formally recognized by Pope Honorius III in 1223.
ref_descr: Arrives to bring Guido da Montefeltro into Heaven, but is forestalled.

name: Saint Francis of Assisi (1182–1226)
description: Son of a wealthy merchant, he spurned his father's riches and founded the Franciscan Order, formally recognized by Pope Honorius III in 1223.
ref_descr: Eulogised by Thomas Aquinas.

name: Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor
description: Was renowned for his Epicurean lifestyle, and alleged to have punished traitors by cloaking them in leaden capes and placing them into boiling cauldrons.
ref_descr: Among the Epicurean heretics.

name: Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor
description: Was renowned for his Epicurean lifestyle, and alleged to have punished traitors by cloaking them in leaden capes and placing them into boiling cauldrons.
ref_descr: His capes compared to those of the hypocrites.

name: Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor
description: Was renowned for his Epicurean lifestyle, and alleged to have punished traitors by cloaking them in leaden capes and placing them into boiling cauldrons.
ref_descr: His government of Italy viewed favorably.

name: Vanni Fucci
description: Nicknamed Bestia, for his brutality, he was the Illegitimate son of Fuccio de' Lazzari. He took part in the vicious struggles that divided his city Pistoia, siding with the Black Guelphs, repeatedly sacked the houses of his political enemies. In 1293, he stole the reliquary of San Jacopo from the sacristy of the Cathedral of Pistoia, for which crime the innocent Rampino Foresi was arrested and nearly executed, before the guilt of Fucci and his accomplices was discovered.
ref_descr: Among the thieves, like the mythical phoenix, he is burned to ashes and restored.

name: Vanni Fucci
description: Nicknamed Bestia, for his brutality, he was the Illegitimate son of Fuccio de' Lazzari. He took part in the vicious struggles that divided his city Pistoia, siding with the Black Guelphs, repeatedly sacked the houses of his political enemies. In 1293, he stole the reliquary of San Jacopo from the sacristy of the Cathedral of Pistoia, for which crime the innocent Rampino Foresi was arrested and nearly executed, before the guilt of Fucci and his accomplices was discovered.
ref_descr: Refers to himself as a "mule" meaning "bastard" ("mul ch'i' fui").

name: Vanni Fucci
description: Nicknamed Bestia, for his brutality, he was the Illegitimate son of Fuccio de' Lazzari. He took part in the vicious struggles that divided his city Pistoia, siding with the Black Guelphs, repeatedly sacked the houses of his political enemies. In 1293, he stole the reliquary of San Jacopo from the sacristy of the Cathedral of Pistoia, for which crime the innocent Rampino Foresi was arrested and nearly executed, before the guilt of Fucci and his accomplices was discovered.
ref_descr: Prophesies the triumph in Florence of the Black Guelphs over the Whites.

name: Vanni Fucci
description: Nicknamed Bestia, for his brutality, he was the Illegitimate son of Fuccio de' Lazzari. He took part in the vicious struggles that divided his city Pistoia, siding with the Black Guelphs, repeatedly sacked the houses of his political enemies. In 1293, he stole the reliquary of San Jacopo from the sacristy of the Cathedral of Pistoia, for which crime the innocent Rampino Foresi was arrested and nearly executed, before the guilt of Fucci and his accomplices was discovered.
ref_descr: Swears against God while performing an obscene gesture (a "fig", the insertion of a thumb between the first and second fingers of a closed fist).

name: Gabriel
description: One of the Archangels of Christian tradition. He was the angel who announced the conception of Jesus to the Virgin Mary.
ref_descr: Beatrice tells Dante that Gabriel may be depicted in human form, but that this form is an accommodation to the limits of the human imagination.

name: Galen (131–201)
description: Ancient Greek physician.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Ganymede
description: Young Trojan prince abducted by Zeus in the form of an eagle and carried to Olympus to serve as cupbearer in the court of the gods.
ref_descr: Dante compares himself to Ganymede when he dreams in his first night in Purgatory that he is carried by an eagle into the heavens.

name: Garisenda
description: A 160-foot leaning tower in Bologna built in the 12th century.
ref_descr: Comparable in size to the giant Antaeus.

name: Geri del Bello
description: A second cousin of Dante. Apparently he was killed by the Sacchetti family and avenged by the Alegheri in 1310, with the feud continuing until 1342.
ref_descr: Of whom Dante says "...a spirit born of my own blood ... his death by violence for which he still is not avenged".

name: Geryon
description: In Greek mythology, son of Chrysaor and Callirhoe, was a winged giant. The tenth labour of Herakles was to steal his cattle. In medieval times, he was viewed as an example of treacherous deception, which may explain Dante's choice of him as an emblem of fraud.
ref_descr: Guardian of the eighth circle, summoned by Virgil, he is encountered in close association with the usurers.

name: Geryon
description: In Greek mythology, son of Chrysaor and Callirhoe, was a winged giant. The tenth labour of Herakles was to steal his cattle. In medieval times, he was viewed as an example of treacherous deception, which may explain Dante's choice of him as an emblem of fraud.
ref_descr: "La fiera con la coda aguzza, che passa i monti, e rompe i muri e l'armi!...colei che tutto 'l mondo appuzza!" ("The beast who bears the pointed tail, who crosses mountains, shatters weapons, walls!...the one whose stench fills all the worlds!").

name: Geryon
description: In Greek mythology, son of Chrysaor and Callirhoe, was a winged giant. The tenth labour of Herakles was to steal his cattle. In medieval times, he was viewed as an example of treacherous deception, which may explain Dante's choice of him as an emblem of fraud.
ref_descr: Carries Virgil and Dante on his back.

name: Geryon
description: In Greek mythology, son of Chrysaor and Callirhoe, was a winged giant. The tenth labour of Herakles was to steal his cattle. In medieval times, he was viewed as an example of treacherous deception, which may explain Dante's choice of him as an emblem of fraud.
ref_descr: Sets down Virgil and Dante in the eighth circle.

name: Geryon
description: In Greek mythology, son of Chrysaor and Callirhoe, was a winged giant. The tenth labour of Herakles was to steal his cattle. In medieval times, he was viewed as an example of treacherous deception, which may explain Dante's choice of him as an emblem of fraud.
ref_descr: Before Dante passes through the fire of Purgatory, Virgil reminds him that he was safe even while riding Geryon.

name: Gideon
description: Hero of ancient Israel. According to Judges 7:4–7, he selected the best warriors by the way they drank their water.
ref_descr: Cited as examples of temperance and gluttony by a voice hidden in a tree of temptation.

name: Giotto
description: Florentine painter. (1266/7–1337)
ref_descr: Mentioned in Purgatory as the most famous painter of the day.

name: Giovanni di Buiamonte dei Becchi
description: Florentine banker, he had held several important offices which earned him a knighthood.
ref_descr: The "sovereign cavalier", whose future damnation as a usurers is alluded to by Reginaldo Scrovegni.

name: Glaucus
description: Ancient Greek mortal changed into an immortal sea god by eating magical reeds at the sea-shore.
ref_descr: Dante claims that he experiences a similar loss of mortality looking on Beatrice.

name: Gloria in excelsis Deo
description: "Glory to God in the Highest." Opening of a canticle sung in morning prayer services and at the beginning of the Latin Mass.
ref_descr: Sung by souls in Purgatory when a soul becomes free to ascend into Paradise.

name: Fra Gomita
description: Chancellor of Nino Visconti and Governor of the giudicato of Gallura, in Sardinia—at the time a possession of Pisa. He accepted a bribe to let escape a group of Visconti's enemies who were in his custody. For this he was hanged.
ref_descr: Among the barrators with Michele Zanche, "a dir di Sardigna le lingue lor non si sentono stanche" ("their tongues are never too tired to speak of their Sardinia").

name: Gratian
description: 12th-century canon lawyer and Camaldolese monk.
ref_descr: Pointed out by Thomas Aquinas in the sphere of the Sun.

name: Pope Gregory
description: Gregory I "the Great" (590–604).
ref_descr: According to medieval legend, when Pope Gregory prayed for the Emperor Trajan, the emperor was raised from the dead and converted to Christianity.

name: Griffin
description: Legendary creature with the body of a lion and the head and wings of an eagle.
ref_descr: In the allegorical Pageant of the Church Triumphant, a griffin representing Christ draws a chariot representing the Church. Dante chose a griffin because its two noble natures (lion and eagle) correspond to the two natures (divine and human) of Christ.

name: Griffolino of Arezzo
description: He duped Alberto da Siena saying, that for money, he would teach him to fly. As a result, Griffolino was burned at the stake for heresy by the Bishop of Siena, who favored Alberto, who was perhaps the Bishop's illegitimate son.
ref_descr: Among the "falsifiers" of metal (alchemists), sitting with Capocchio, propping each other up, as they frantically scratch at the scabs covering their bodies.

name: Griffolino of Arezzo
description: He duped Alberto da Siena saying, that for money, he would teach him to fly. As a result, Griffolino was burned at the stake for heresy by the Bishop of Siena, who favored Alberto, who was perhaps the Bishop's illegitimate son.
ref_descr: He introduces himself.

name: Griffolino of Arezzo
description: He duped Alberto da Siena saying, that for money, he would teach him to fly. As a result, Griffolino was burned at the stake for heresy by the Bishop of Siena, who favored Alberto, who was perhaps the Bishop's illegitimate son.
ref_descr: Referred to as "the Aretine", he identifies Schicchi and Myrrha.

name: Guelphs and Ghibellines
description: Factions supporting, respectively, the Papacy and the Holy Roman Empire in Italy during the 12th and 13th centuries. After the Guelphs finally defeated the Ghibellines in 1289 at Campaldino and Caprona, (Dante apparently fought for the Guelphs at both), they began to fight among themselves. By 1300, Dante's city, Florence, was "divided" between the Black Guelphs, who continued to support the Papacy, and White Guelphs, Dante's party. That year the Whites defeated the Blacks and forced them out of Florence, however, in 1302, the Blacks, with the help of Pope Boniface VIII, were victorious and the Whites, including Dante, were banished from Florence. Inf. VI, 60–72.
ref_descr: Florence the divided city.

name: Guido Guerra (c. 1220–1272)
description: Member of one of the greatest Tuscan families, he was one of the leaders of the Guelph faction in Florence, under whose banners he fought the disastrous battle of Montaperti in 1260. Exiled following the triumph of the Ghibellines, he returned to Florence in 1267 when the Guelphs retook control of the city.
ref_descr: One of a group of three Florentine sodomites who approach Dante, and are much esteemed by him (see Jacopo Rusticucci).

name: Guido Guerra (c. 1220–1272)
description: Member of one of the greatest Tuscan families, he was one of the leaders of the Guelph faction in Florence, under whose banners he fought the disastrous battle of Montaperti in 1260. ref_descr: "In sua vita fece col senno assai e con la spada" ("In his life he did much with the senses and the sword").

name: Guido Guinizelli
description: Italian poet (c. 1230–1276). Dante considered him the founder of his style of poetry (Dolce Stil Novo).
ref_descr: Dante meets him on the terrace of lustful.

name: Guido da Montefeltro (1223–1298)
description: Renowned leader of the Ghibellines of Romagna. As ruler of Forlì, in 1282, he defeated a French force, which was besieging the city. In 1296 he retired from military life and entered the Franciscan order. Pope Boniface VIII, in 1297, asked his advice on how to capture Palestrina, the impegnable stronghold of the Colonna family, offering in advance papal absolution for any sin his advice might entail. He advised Boniface to promise the Colonnas amnesty, then break it. As a result, the Collonas surrendered the fortress and it was razed to the ground. Dante also mentions him in the Convivio, where he curiously extols his piety and sanctity.
ref_descr: Among the fraudulent counsellors.

ref_descr: He "made a bloody heap out of the French".

name: Guido da Polenta
description: The powerful aristocratic ruler of Ravenna and Cervia, the former town taken by him in 1275 and the latter shortly after. He was father of Francesca da Rimini, and grandfather of Guido Novello da Ravenna, who was to give Dante hospitality in his last years. The coat of arms of his family contained an eagle.
ref_descr: "The Eagle of Polenta".

name: Robert Guiscard (c. 1015–1085)
description: One of the most remarkable of the Norman adventurers who conquered Southern Italy and Sicily. He was count (1057–1059) and then duke (1059–1085) of Apulia and Calabria after his brother Humphrey's death.
ref_descr: His warring in Apulia.

name: Guy de Montfort
description: Son of Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester (1208–1265) who was leader of the baronial opposition to king Henry III of England. Simon was killed at the battle of Evesham and Guy revenged his death by killing the king's nephew, another Henry, in a church in Viterbo.
ref_descr: Pointed out by Nessus.

name: Hadrian V
description: Pope for 38 days in 1276.
ref_descr: Dante encounters him repenting for his greed in the terrace of the greedy.

name: Hannibal
description: Ancient military leader of Carthage, who led an invasion of "Arabs" over the Alps into Italy in the Second Punic War in the late 3rd century BCE.
ref_descr: His defeat cited as a triumph of the early Roman Republic.

name: Harpies
description: Monsters from Greek mythology with human female faces on the bodies of birds.
ref_descr: Tormentors of the suicides in the seventh circle, round 2. Their description is derived from Virgil (Aeneid iii, 209 on), which tells how they drove the Trojans from the Strophades.

name: Hector
description: The greatest Trojan warrior, in the Trojan War.
ref_descr: Seen in Limbo.

name: Hecuba
description: Wife of Priam king of Troy, mother of Hector, Paris, Polyxena and Polydorus. Captured after the fall of Troy, she went mad after seeing her daughter Polyxena, sacrificed on the tomb of Achilles and the corpse of her son Polydorus, murdered by Polymestor, King of Thrace (Euripides, Hecuba, Ovid Metamorphoses XIII, 429–575). According to Ovid she growled and barked like a mad dog.
ref_descr: Her "fury" at the deaths of Polyxena and Polydorus.

name: Helen
description: Wife of the Spartan king Menelaus and lover of the Trojan Paris, her abduction caused the Trojan War.
ref_descr: Found amongst the sexual sinners.

name: Heliodorus
description: Minister to Seleucus IV, Hellenistic ruler of the Seleucid Empire. According to II Maccabees 3:21–28, he was sent to Jerusalem to plunder the treasury of the Temple, but was turned back by supernatural figures, including a man mounted on a horse.
ref_descr: Cited by souls on the terrace of the greedy as an example of greed.

name: Hellespont
description: Narrow strait connecting the Black Sea with the Aegean Sea and separating Europe from Asia Minor. In Herodotus' account of the Persian Wars, Xerxes, king of the Persians, spanned the Hellespont with a bridge to invade Greece. When a storm destroyed the bridge, the king ordered his soldiers to flog the waters as punishment.
ref_descr: Dante compares the narrow Lethe River to the narrow Hellespont.

name: Hellespont
description: Narrow strait connecting the Black Sea with the Aegean Sea and separating Europe from Asia Minor. In Herodotus' account of the Persian Wars, Xerxes, king of the Persians, spanned the Hellespont with a bridge to invade Greece. When a storm destroyed the bridge, the king ordered his soldiers to flog the waters as punishment.
ref_descr: The ancient towns of Abydos and Sestos were on the shores of the Hellespont.

name: Henry of England (Arrigo d'Inghilterra)
description: Henry III (1216–1272)
ref_descr: Dante sees him in the "Valley of the Princes," waiting as a late-repenter to enter Purgatory.

name: Heraclitus (c. 535 –c. 475 BCE)
description: Greek Presocratic philosopher.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Hera (Juno in Roman mythology)
description: Greek goddess, she is the wife of Zeus (Jupiter). A jealous goddess, she often sought revenge against Zeus' many lovers. One of those was Semele, who was the daughter of Cadmus, King of Thebes and the mother of Dionysus by Zeus. One of Hera's many acts of revenge against Semele, was to cause Athamas, husband of Semele's sister Ino, to be driven mad. Mistaking Ino, holding their two infant sons Learchus and Melicertes, for a lioness and her cubs, he killed Learchus, and Ino still holding Melicertes jumped off a cliff into the sea. (Ovid, Metamorphoses IV, 416–542). Another lover of Zeus, and victim of Hera was Aegina, daughter of the river-god Asopus (see Aegina above).
ref_descr: Her revenge against "Aegina's people".

ref_descr: Her (Juno's) revenge against Semeles' "Theban family".

name: Heracles (Latin
description: Hercules): Son of Zeus and Alcmene, he is probably the most famous Hero of Greek mythology. Of his many achievements, the most famous are the Twelve Labours.
ref_descr: His victory over Cacus.

name: Heracles (Latin
description: Hercules): Son of Zeus and Alcmene, he is probably the most famous Hero of Greek mythology. Of his many achievements, the most famous are the Twelve Labours.
ref_descr: Ulysses recounts his passing the Pillars of Hercules at the Strait of Gibraltar, where "Hercules set up his boundary stones that men might heed and never reach beyond".

name: Hippocrates (c. 460–380 BCE)
description: Ancient Greek physician, often called "the father of medicine.".
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Hippocrates (c. 460–380 BCE)
description: Ancient Greek physician, often called "the father of medicine.".
ref_descr: Dante identifies St. Luke in the Pageant of the Church Triumphant as a disciple of Hippocrates. Ancient tradition holds that Luke was a physician.

name: Holofernes
description: According to the Book of Judith, an Assyrian general who invades Israel. He is killed by Judith, who seduces him in his tent.
ref_descr: Depicted on the pavement in Purgatory as an example of arrogance.

name: Homer
description: Greek poet credited with the authorship of the epic poems the Iliad, which tells the story of the Trojan War, and the Odyssey, which tells the story of the Greek hero Odysseus' adventures returning from that war.
ref_descr: Encountered in Limbo, leading, "as lord", the three Latin poets Horace, Ovid and Lucan.

name: Homer
description: Greek poet credited with the authorship of the epic poems the Iliad, which tells the story of the Trojan War, and the Odyssey, which tells the story of the Greek hero Odysseus' adventures returning from that war.
ref_descr: "The lord of song incomparable who like an eagle soars above the rest."

name: Homer
description: Greek poet credited with the authorship of the epic poems the Iliad, which tells the story of the Trojan War, and the Odyssey, which tells the story of the Greek hero Odysseus' adventures returning from that war.
ref_descr: The poets ask Dante "to join their ranks",

name: Homer
description: Greek poet credited with the authorship of the epic poems the Iliad, which tells the story of the Trojan War, and the Odyssey, which tells the story of the Greek hero Odysseus' adventures returning from that war.
ref_descr: Dante and Virgil leave the company of the poets.

name: Horace
description: Latin lyric poet.
ref_descr: One of a group of classical poets (see Homer) encountered in Limbo.

name: Hugh Capet
description: (c. 939–996) First King of the Franks and founder of the Capetian Dynasty.
ref_descr: Dante encounters him on the terrace of the greedy, where Hugh laments the greed of his successors to the French throne.

name: Hypsipyle
description: Queen of Lemnos, she was seduced and abandoned by Jason while en route to the Colchis with the Argonauts.
ref_descr: Pitied by Virgil for Jason's actions.

name: Hypsipyle
description: Queen of Lemnos, she was seduced and abandoned by Jason while en route to the Colchis with the Argonauts.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Icarus
description: In Greek mythology, the son of the inventor Daedalus. They escaped from imprisonment in Crete using wings of feathers and wax invented by Daedalus. However, Icarus flew too near the Sun, the wax melted, and he fell to his death.
ref_descr: Used as a simile for fear in

name: "In te, Domine, speravi" ("In Thee, o Lord, have I hoped")
description: Incipit of Psalm 31 in Latin (Psalm 30 in the Vulgate Bible)
ref_descr: First nine verses of the psalm sung by the angels when Dante meets Beatrice.

name: "In exitu Isräel de Aegypto"
description: ("When Israel came out of Egypt"): Latin incipit of Psalm 114 (Psalm 113 in the Vulgate Bible).
ref_descr: Sung by souls arriving in Purgatory.

name: Indus River
description: major river of Asia which flows through present day Pakistan and India, with its source in the Tibetan Himalayas.
ref_descr: The eagle of justice takes the shores of the Indus to represent those regions of the world where news of Christ has never reached and so justice cannot condemn the people for living without baptism,

name: Alessio Interminelli
description: Member of a White Guelph noble family of Lucca. He probably died in 1295.
ref_descr: Found among the flatterers.

name: Iphigenia
description: In Greek legend, daughter of Agamemnon and Clytemnestra. Her father intended to sacrifice her in order to placate the gods who withholding winds to carry the Greek fleet to Troy.
ref_descr: Beatrice cites the vow to sacrifice Iphigenia as an example of an injudicious vow that never should have been kept.

name: Iris
description: Greek personification of rainbows and messenger of the gods.
ref_descr: Mentioned in relation to rainbows.

name: Isaac
description: The biblical father of the patriarch Israel.
ref_descr: Raised by Jesus from Limbo into Paradise.

name: Isidore of Seville
description: Archbishop of Seville, and one of the great scholars of the early Middle Ages.
ref_descr: Encountered in the Fourth Sphere of Heaven (The sun).

name: Israel
description: One name given to the biblical patriarch Jacob.
ref_descr: Raised by Jesus from Limbo into Paradise.

name: Jacopo da Santo Andrea
description: Notorious spendthrift from Padua. He may have been executed by Ezzelino da Romano in 1239.
ref_descr: One of two spendthrifts (the other called "Lano" is probably Arcolano of Siena) whose punishment consists of being hunted by female hounds.

name: Jason
description: Greek mythological hero who led the Argonauts to Colchis in search of the Golden Fleece.
ref_descr: Found among the Seducers, for his seduction and abandonment of Hypsipyle and Medea.

name: Jason
description: Greek mythological hero who led the Argonauts to Colchis in search of the Golden Fleece.
ref_descr: The Argonauts' voyage compared to a voyage into the mysteries of the heavens.

name: Jason
description: Brother of the High Priest of Israel Onias III, he succeeded his brother in c. 175 BCE. According to 2 Maccabees he obtained his office by bribing the Seleucid king Antiochus IV Epiphanes.
ref_descr: Pope Clement V is compared to him.

name: Jehoshaphat
description: Fourth king of the Kingdom of Judah.
ref_descr: Mentioned in relation to the end of time.

name: Jephthah
description: Judge in ancient Israel who made a careless vow to offer up a sacrifice of thanksgiving for victory in battle and accidentally committed his daughter to that sacrifice. The story appears in Judges 11.
ref_descr: Beatrice cites Jephthah as an example of poor judgment.

name: Jerusalem
description: Location of the Temple of Solomon and site of Jesus' crucifixion. Considered in the Middle Ages as the geographical center of the inhabited world.
ref_descr: Hell is located directly below Jerusalem.

name: Jerusalem
description: Location of the Temple of Solomon and site of Jesus' crucifixion. Considered in the Middle Ages as the geographical center of the inhabited world.
ref_descr: Purgatory is a mountain at the antipodes of Jerusalem.

name: Jesus
description: Central figure of Christianity. According to Christian legend, in what is called the Harrowing of Hell, he descended into Hell after his death and rescued certain souls from Limbo.
ref_descr: Virgil describes witnessing his descent into Hell.

name: Jesus
description: Central figure of Christianity. According to Christian legend, in what is called the Harrowing of Hell, he descended into Hell after his death and rescued certain souls from Limbo.
ref_descr: Took spoils from Dis in the Harrowing of Hell.

name: Jesus
description: Central figure of Christianity. According to Christian legend, in what is called the Harrowing of Hell, he descended into Hell after his death and rescued certain souls from Limbo.
ref_descr: Unlike the souls being punished for simony, Jesus asked no gold from Saint Peter in exchange for his office.

name: Jesus
description: Central figure of Christianity. According to Christian legend, in what is called the Harrowing of Hell, he descended into Hell after his death and rescued certain souls from Limbo.
ref_descr: In his only appearance in the Comedy, he is seen in the form of a Griffin in the Pageant of the Church Triumphant.

name: Jocasta
description: Wife and mother of Oedipus, ancient king of Thebes. They had two sons, Polynices and Eteocles. Statius' Thebaid tells the story of the family conflict.
ref_descr: Mentioned as the subject of Statius' work.

name: John the Baptist
description: The desert prophet, who baptised Jesus. He became the patron saint of Florence, displacing the Roman Mars, and his image was stamped on the cities gold coin, the florin.
ref_descr: In Florence, "the first patron gave way" to him.

name: John the Baptist
description: The desert prophet, who baptised Jesus. He became the patron saint of Florence, displacing the Roman Mars, and his image was stamped on the cities gold coin, the florin.
ref_descr: "The currency which bears" his seal.

name: John the Baptist
description: The desert prophet, who baptised Jesus. He became the patron saint of Florence, displacing the Roman Mars, and his image was stamped on the cities gold coin, the florin.
ref_descr: A voice in Purgatory on the terrace of the gluttonous cites John as an example in Temperance.

name: Jordan
description: River on the border of Israel.
ref_descr: Crossed by ancient Israelites led by Joshua after an older, less eager generation had died off. Mentioned as a lesson in sloth.

name: Judas Iscariot
description: Disciple who betrayed Jesus.
ref_descr: Virgil's visit to "Judas' circle".

name: Judas Iscariot
description: Disciple who betrayed Jesus.
ref_descr: "The transgressing soul" replaced by Saint Matthias.

name: Judas Iscariot
description: Disciple who betrayed Jesus.
ref_descr: Along with Brutus and Cassius, one of the three betrayer/suicides who, for those sins, were eternally chewed by one of the three mouths of Satan.

name: Judas Iscariot
description: Disciple who betrayed Jesus.
ref_descr: The innermost ring of Cocytus, where the treacherous to masters and benefactors are punished, is named Judecca.

name: Julia
description: Daughter of Julius Caesar and wife of Pompey.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Julius Caesar (100–44 BCE)
description: The celebrated Roman dictator and military commander.
ref_descr: Virgil's remembers him (erroneously) as ruler of Rome at his birth.

name: Julius Caesar (100–44 BCE)
description: The celebrated Roman dictator and military commander.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo, "armato con li occhi grifagni" ("falcon-eyed and fully armed").

name: Julius Caesar (100–44 BCE)
description: The celebrated Roman dictator and military commander.
ref_descr: Advised by Curio to lead his army across the Rubicon, which is considered an act of war against the Roman Republic.

name: Julius Caesar (100–44 BCE)
description: The celebrated Roman dictator and military commander.
ref_descr: Souls in the terrace of sloth cite his campaigns in France and Spain as an inspiring example of energy.

name: Julius Caesar (100–44 BCE)
description: The celebrated Roman dictator and military commander.
ref_descr: His rumored sexual relations with Bithynian King Nicomedes mentioned on the terrace of the lustful.

name: Julius Caesar (100–44 BCE)
description: The celebrated Roman dictator and military commander.
ref_descr: His unlawful entry into Rome cited as the beginning of the Roman Empire which ultimately brought an imperial peace to the world.

name: Justinian
description: Flavius Petrus Sabbatius Iustinianus, an emperor of Byzantium, known as "the last Roman emperor". A saintly man respected for his law reforms.
ref_descr: His "mending [Italy's] bridle".

name: Encountered in the Second Sphere
description: Mercury, as an unnamed "holy form [concealed] within his rays". Par. V, 115–139.
ref_descr: His discourse on the history of Rome.

name: Encountered in the Second Sphere
description: Mercury, as an unnamed "holy form [concealed] within his rays". Par. V, 115–139.
ref_descr: His description of the souls in Mercury.

name: Juvenal
description: Decimus Iunius Iuvenalis, Roman poet of the 1st and 2nd centuries CE.
ref_descr: On arrival in Limbo, he informed Virgil about Statius' poetic accomplishments.

name: "Kill! Kill!" ("Martira, martira!")
description: The martyrdom of St. Stephen by an angry mob. He died without anger as he was stoned to death. His last words were a prayer for forgiveness for his enemies. (Acts 7:58–60)
ref_descr: Seen in a vision by Dante as he enters the terrace of the angry in Purgatory.

name: "Labïa mëa, Domine"
description: Abbreviation of "Domine, labia mea aperies; et os meum annunciabit laudem tuam." ("O Lord, open thou my lips, and my mouth shall proclaim thy praise.") (Psalm 51:15; Ps 50:15 in the Vulgate.) Verse recited at the beginning of the first monastic prayer office of the day.
ref_descr: Chanted in penitence by souls on the terrace of the gluttonous in Purgatory.

name: Lacedaemon
description: Also known as Sparta, a leading city in ancient Greece.
ref_descr: Dante commends Lacedaemon as an example of orderly government.

name: Lachesis
description: One of the three Fates in Greco-Roman mythology. With a measuring rod, she measures out the life-span of every mortal.
ref_descr: Mentioned with reference to death.

name: Laertes
description: Mythical father of Odysseus (Ulysses), he was one of the Argonauts. In the Odyssey he takes part in the massacre of Penelope's suitors.
ref_descr: Not even Ulysses' love for his father (and wife and son) was enough to overrule his desire "to gain experience of the world and of the vices and the worth of men".

name: Lancelot
description: Central figure of the Arthurian legend.
ref_descr: Reading tales of his amorous adventures led Paulo and Francesca astray.

name: Lateran Palace
description: The principle papal residence, from the beginning of the 4th century, until the beginning of Avignon Papacy, in 1305.
ref_descr: Used by Dante to allude to Boniface's warring against Christians, rather than "Jews" or "Saracens".

name: Lateran Palace
description: The principle papal residence, from the beginning of the 4th century, until the beginning of Avignon Papacy, in 1305.
ref_descr: Dante is struck by the magnificence of heaven like barbarians invading Rome were struck by the city's wonder in the era when "the Lateran / Above all mortal things was eminent."

name: Lavinia
description: Daughter of Latinus and Amata and wife of Aeneas.
ref_descr: One of a group of figures associated with the history of Troy, Virgil's Aeneid, and the history of Rome encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Lavinia
description: Daughter of Latinus and Amata and wife of Aeneas.
ref_descr: Dante has a vision of Lavinia mourning for her mother Amata, who committed suicide after inciting a war between the Latins and the Trojans. The vision comes as Dante departs the terrace of the angry in Purgatory.

name: Lawrence
description: Deacon in the Church in Rome, martyred in 258. According to tradition, he was tied to a grate and burned to death.
ref_descr: Beatrice cites Lawrence as an example of a steadfast will.

name: Leah
description: Sister to Rachel, first wife of Jacob, and mother of six of the tribes of ancient Israel. She was the less attractive of the two sisters, but Jacob was tricked into marrying her first. (Gen 29:16–25)
ref_descr: In a dream, Dante sees her gathering flowers.

name: Lethe
description: One of the rivers of Hades in Greek mythology. To drink its waters is to forget everything. In the Comedy, its source is in Terrestrial Paradise at the top of Purgatory. When it reaches the base of the mountain, it flows down a narrow passageway to the center of the Earth.
ref_descr: Its location is asked about and given.

name: Lethe
description: One of the rivers of Hades in Greek mythology. To drink its waters is to forget everything. In the Comedy, its source is in Terrestrial Paradise at the top of Purgatory. When it reaches the base of the mountain, it flows down a narrow passageway to the center of the Earth.
ref_descr: Probably the little stream Dante hears at the center of the Earth.

name: Lethe
description: One of the rivers of Hades in Greek mythology. To drink its waters is to forget everything. In the Comedy, its source is in Terrestrial Paradise at the top of Purgatory. When it reaches the base of the mountain, it flows down a narrow passageway to the center of the Earth.
ref_descr: Guido Guinizelli tells Dante that even Lethe will not erase his memory of their conversation.

description: One of the rivers of Hades in Greek mythology. To drink its waters is to forget everything. In the Comedy, its source is in Terrestrial Paradise at the top of Purgatory. When it reaches the base of the mountain, it flows down a narrow passageway to the center of the Earth.
ref_descr: Dante arrives at its banks.

name: Lethe
description: One of the rivers of Hades in Greek mythology. To drink its waters is to forget everything. In the Comedy, its source is in Terrestrial Paradise at the top of Purgatory. When it reaches the base of the mountain, it flows down a narrow passageway to the center of the Earth.
ref_descr: Matilda explains that its source is miraculous because there is no rain in Terrestrial Paradise.

name: Lethe
description: One of the rivers of Hades in Greek mythology. To drink its waters is to forget everything. In the Comedy, its source is in Terrestrial Paradise at the top of Purgatory. When it reaches the base of the mountain, it flows down a narrow passageway to the center of the Earth.
ref_descr: Dante must repent of his infidelity to Beatrice before he is allowed to drink from the Lethe and forget the act.

name: Lethe
description: One of the rivers of Hades in Greek mythology. To drink its waters is to forget everything. In the Comedy, its source is in Terrestrial Paradise at the top of Purgatory. When it reaches the base of the mountain, it flows down a narrow passageway to the center of the Earth.
ref_descr: Matilda bears Dante through the Lethe.

name: Lethe
description: One of the rivers of Hades in Greek mythology. To drink its waters is to forget everything. In the Comedy, its source is in Terrestrial Paradise at the top of Purgatory. When it reaches the base of the mountain, it flows down a narrow passageway to the center of the Earth.
ref_descr: Dante sees the source of the Lethe in Terrestrial Paradise.

name: Levi
description: Son of Jacob and Leah and eponymous forebear of a tribe of ancient Israel. The tribe of Levi was responsible for duties of worship and did not receive a tribal homeland.
ref_descr: Dante refers to the clergy as "Levi's sons."

name: Libra
description: Constellation of the zodiac. During the events of the Comedy, it would be highest in the sky at about 1 A.M.
ref_descr: Used to indicate the time of day.

name: Linus
description: Mythical son of Apollo who taught music to Orpheus.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Livy (c. 59 BCE – 17 CE)
description: The famous Roman historian author of the monumental Ab Urbe Condita, telling the history of Rome from the origins down to his own times.
ref_descr: The historian "who does not err".

name: Lombards
description: Germanic tribe who invaded Italy in the 6th century BCE and established a kingdom in the northern part of the peninsula.
ref_descr: The conquering Lombards were Arian Christians in belief, where they came into conflict with the Catholic Church in Rome.

name: Peter Lombard (c. 1090–1160)
description: Theologian and Bishop; author of The Sentences, a famous medieval textbook of theology.
ref_descr: Pointed out by Thomas Aquinas in the sphere of the Sun.

name: Lucan (39–65)
description: Latin poet, whose Pharsalia, an epic poem on the civil war between Julius Caesar and Pompey, is an important source for Dante. Like Seneca he was forced to commit suicide by Nero for his participation in the Pisonian conspiracy.
ref_descr: One of a group of classical poets (see Homer) encountered in Limbo.

name: Lucan (39–65)
description: Latin poet, whose Pharsalia, an epic poem on the civil war between Julius Caesar and Pompey, is an important source for Dante. Like Seneca he was forced to commit suicide by Nero for his participation in the Pisonian conspiracy.
ref_descr: The serpents in the Malebolge comes from his Pharsalia (IX, 710 ff).

name: Lucan (39–65)
description: Latin poet, whose Pharsalia, an epic poem on the civil war between Julius Caesar and Pompey, is an important source for Dante. Like Seneca he was forced to commit suicide by Nero for his participation in the Pisonian conspiracy.
ref_descr: His description in Pharsalia (IX, 761–804) of the deaths and "transformations" of Sabellus and Nasidiusis is compared with the transformations of the thieves and sinners in the Malebolge.

name: Lucia of Syracuse
description: (Saint Lucy) 4th-century martyr saint associated with light and those, like Dante, who suffered from poor eyesight. She symbolises Illuminating Grace in the poem.
ref_descr: Serves as an intermediary between the "gentle lady" (see Mary) and Beatrice.

name: Lucia of Syracuse
