description: (Saint Lucy) 4th-century martyr saint associated with light and those, like Dante, who suffered from poor eyesight. She symbolises Illuminating Grace in the poem.
ref_descr: Lifts Dante in his sleep to the Gate of St. Peter in Purgatory.

name: Lucretia
description: Legendary woman in the history of the Roman Republic, whose rape by the son of king Tarquinius Superbus was revenged by Brutus when he overthrew the king.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Lucretia
description: Legendary woman in the history of the Roman Republic, whose rape by the son of king Tarquinius Superbus was revenged by Brutus when he overthrew the king.
ref_descr: Cited as a reason for the end of Roman monarchy.

name: Luke
description: Writer of the third Gospel. Luke includes a story of the resurrected Jesus quietly joining two disciples as they walked the road to Emmaus. (Luke 24:13–27)
ref_descr: When Statius joins Virgil and Dante as they walked in Purgatory, Dante compares the meeting to the event in Luke.

name: Lycurgus
description: Ancient king of Nemea. According to Statius's Thebaid (V.499–730), Lycurgus received Hypsipyle and her two sons as refugees from Lemnos and put his own son in her care. When she accidentally permitted the Lycurgus' son to die of a snakebite, the enraged king wanted to kill her. Her two sons rushed to her side to protect her.
ref_descr: Mentioned by Dante.

name: Malatesta da Verucchio
description: Founder of the powerful Malatesta family, he and his son Malatestino, were Guelph rulers of Rimini from 1295, who killed the chief members of the rival Ghibelline family, the Parcitati, including their leader Montagna de' Parcitati. Malatesta had two other sons Giovanni, who married Guido da Polenta's daughter Francesca, and Paolo who became her lover (see Paolo and Francesca).
ref_descr: The old mastiff of Verucchio".

name: Malatestino
description: Son of Malatesta da Verrucchio, after his father's death in 1312, he became Signore of Rimini. He had two nobles of Fano, Guido del Cassero and Angiolello di Carignano, drowned, after he had summoned them to a parley at Cattolica.
ref_descr: The new mastiff of Verruchio.

name: Malatestino
description: Son of Malatesta da Verrucchio, after his father's death in 1312, he became Signore of Rimini. He had two nobles of Fano, Guido del Cassero and Angiolello di Carignano, drowned, after he had summoned them to a parley at Cattolica.
ref_descr: The "foul tyrant" and "traitor who sees only with one eye", his betrayal of Guido and Angiolello.

name: Malebolge ("evil-pouches")
description: The eighth circle of Dante's hell, it contains ten trenches wherein the ten types of "ordinary" fraud are punished.
ref_descr: Encountered.

name: Malebolge ("evil-pouches")
description: The eighth circle of Dante's hell, it contains ten trenches wherein the ten types of "ordinary" fraud are punished.
ref_descr: Described as a funnel consisting of concentric and progressively lower ditches.

name: Malebolge ("evil-pouches")
description: The eighth circle of Dante's hell, it contains ten trenches wherein the ten types of "ordinary" fraud are punished.
ref_descr: Its "final cloister" filled with "lay brothers".

name: Malebranche ("evil-claws")
description: In the Inferno, it is the name of a group of demons in the fifth pouch of the Malebolge. They are led by Malacoda ("evil-tail"), who assigns ten of his demons to escort Dante: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo ("big dog"), Barbariccia (leads the ten), Libicocco, Draghignazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane ("dog-scratcher") Farfarello and Rubicante. Another Malebranche is Scarmiglione.
ref_descr: Encountered.

name: Malebranche ("evil-claws")
description: In the Inferno, it is the name of a group of demons in the fifth pouch of the Malebolge. They are led by Malacoda ("evil-tail"), who assigns ten of his demons to escort Dante: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo ("big dog"), Barbariccia (leads the ten), Libicocco, Draghignazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane ("dog-scratcher") Farfarello and Rubicante. Another Malebranche is Scarmiglione.
ref_descr: A demon is described plunging a barrator into a boiling lake of pitch and returning to Lucca "for more".

name: Malebranche ("evil-claws")
description: In the Inferno, it is the name of a group of demons in the fifth pouch of the Malebolge. They are led by Malacoda ("evil-tail"), who assigns ten of his demons to escort Dante: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo ("big dog"), Barbariccia (leads the ten), Libicocco, Draghignazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane ("dog-scratcher") Farfarello and Rubicante. Another Malebranche is Scarmiglione.
ref_descr: Their using prongs to keep the sinner submerged is compared to cooking meat in a pot.

name: Malebranche ("evil-claws")
description: In the Inferno, it is the name of a group of demons in the fifth pouch of the Malebolge. They are led by Malacoda ("evil-tail"), who assigns ten of his demons to escort Dante: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo ("big dog"), Barbariccia (leads the ten), Libicocco, Draghignazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane ("dog-scratcher") Farfarello and Rubicante. Another Malebranche is Scarmiglione.
ref_descr: Escort assigned.

name: Malebranche ("evil-claws")
description: In the Inferno, it is the name of a group of demons in the fifth pouch of the Malebolge. They are led by Malacoda ("evil-tail"), who assigns ten of his demons to escort Dante: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo ("big dog"), Barbariccia (leads the ten), Libicocco, Draghignazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane ("dog-scratcher") Farfarello and Rubicante. Another Malebranche is Scarmiglione.
ref_descr: Scarmiglione.

name: Malebranche ("evil-claws")
description: In the Inferno, it is the name of a group of demons in the fifth pouch of the Malebolge. They are led by Malacoda ("evil-tail"), who assigns ten of his demons to escort Dante: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo ("big dog"), Barbariccia (leads the ten), Libicocco, Draghignazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane ("dog-scratcher") Farfarello and Rubicante. Another Malebranche is Scarmiglione.
ref_descr: Barbarariccia's remarkable trumpet.

name: Malebranche ("evil-claws")
description: In the Inferno, it is the name of a group of demons in the fifth pouch of the Malebolge. They are led by Malacoda ("evil-tail"), who assigns ten of his demons to escort Dante: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo ("big dog"), Barbariccia (leads the ten), Libicocco, Draghignazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane ("dog-scratcher") Farfarello and Rubicante. Another Malebranche is Scarmiglione.
ref_descr: The demons escort Dante, guarding the shore as they go. A sinner is dragged ashore, attacked by the demons and is questioned but escapes, and two demons fight and fall into the boiling pitch.

name: Malebranche ("evil-claws")
description: In the Inferno, it is the name of a group of demons in the fifth pouch of the Malebolge. They are led by Malacoda ("evil-tail"), who assigns ten of his demons to escort Dante: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo ("big dog"), Barbariccia (leads the ten), Libicocco, Draghignazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane ("dog-scratcher") Farfarello and Rubicante. Another Malebranche is Scarmiglione.
ref_descr: Dante and Virgil escape their pursuit.

name: Malebranche ("evil-claws")
description: In the Inferno, it is the name of a group of demons in the fifth pouch of the Malebolge. They are led by Malacoda ("evil-tail"), who assigns ten of his demons to escort Dante: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo ("big dog"), Barbariccia (leads the ten), Libicocco, Draghignazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane ("dog-scratcher") Farfarello and Rubicante. Another Malebranche is Scarmiglione.
ref_descr: Malacoda's lie is discovered.

name: Manfred
description: King of Sicily from 1258 to 1266.
ref_descr: Encountered as an excommunicate in Purgatory, where he waits 30 years for each year of his excommunication.

name: "Manibus, oh, date lilia plenis." ("O, give lilies by the handful.")
description: Quotation from Virgil's Aeneid (VI.883).
ref_descr: Sung by angels in the Pageant of the Church Triumphant, welcoming Beatrice to the procession.

name: Manto
description: Mythical daughter of Tiresias, from her father she inherited the power of prophecy.
ref_descr: Seen among the seers in the 8th circle of Hell.

name: Manto
description: Mythical daughter of Tiresias, from her father she inherited the power of prophecy.
ref_descr: Virgil tells how Manto travelled until she arrived in the spot that was to be called after her Mantua.

name: Manto
description: Mythical daughter of Tiresias, from her father she inherited the power of prophecy.
ref_descr: The "daughter of Tiresias" is among those Virgil says also reside with him in the Limbo of Noble Pagans.

name: Mantua
description: An important and ancient city in Lombardy. Its name is probably of Etruscan origin.
ref_descr: Birthplace of Virgil.

name: Mantua
description: An important and ancient city in Lombardy. Its name is probably of Etruscan origin.
ref_descr: Beatrice addresses Virgil as "courteous Mantuan spirit".

name: Mantua
description: An important and ancient city in Lombardy. Its name is probably of Etruscan origin.
ref_descr: Virgil tells Dante of the origin of the name of Mantua and about its foundation.

name: Mantua
description: An important and ancient city in Lombardy. Its name is probably of Etruscan origin.
ref_descr: Sordello addresses Virgil as "Mantuan".

name: Marcia
description: Wife of Cato the younger.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Marcia
description: Wife of Cato the younger.
ref_descr: Permanently separated from her husband, who guards the entrance to Purgatory.

name: Maremma
description: Area consisting of part of southern Tuscany (and partly coincident with the province of Grosseto) and some part of northern Latium (a bordering region of the province of Viterbo). in Dante's time it was a desolate marshland, plagued by malaria.
ref_descr: Identified as between Cecina and Corneto.

name: Maremma
description: Area consisting of part of southern Tuscany (and partly coincident with the province of Grosseto) and some part of northern Latium (a bordering region of the province of Viterbo). in Dante's time it was a desolate marshland, plagued by malaria.
ref_descr: Reputation for snakes.

name: Maremma
description: Area consisting of part of southern Tuscany (and partly coincident with the province of Grosseto) and some part of northern Latium (a bordering region of the province of Viterbo). in Dante's time it was a desolate marshland, plagued by malaria.
ref_descr: Sickness from July until September.

name: Mars
description: In Roman mythology, the god of war.
ref_descr: As ei per questo//sempre con l'arte sua la farà trista (he who with this art always will make it [Florence] sad) he is identified as the patron of Florence before John the Baptist.

name: Mars
description: In Roman mythology, the god of war.
ref_descr: Depicted in a pavement carving in Purgatory casting Briareus from Olympus.

name: Marsyas
description: Ancient Greek who challenged Apollo to a contest of musical performance judged by the Muses. After Marsyas lost, Apollo flayed him to death.
ref_descr: Dante metaphorically asks Apollo to treat him like Marsyas, by removing his soul from the body in order to write about the heavens.

name: Charles Martel of Anjou (1271–1295)
description: son of Charles II of Naples.
ref_descr: In the sphere of Venus, he discusses degeneracy among noble families, and denounces confusion of vocations.

name: Charles Martel of Anjou (1271–1295)
description: son of Charles II of Naples.
ref_descr: His prophecy.

name: Pope Martin IV
description: Pope from 1281 to 1285. According to Dante, he died after a gluttonous feast of eels and wine.
ref_descr: Dante sees him in the terrace of the gluttons, repenting of his excess.

name: Mary
description: The mother of Jesus.
ref_descr: Probably the "gentle lady", who takes pity on Dante and calls on Lucia to ask Beatrice to help him.

name: Mary
description: The mother of Jesus.
ref_descr: Souls in Purgatory call on Mary to pray for them.

name: Souls on the terrace of sloth quote her "haste" (Luke 1
description: 39) as a spiritual lesson. Purg. XVIII, 99–100.
ref_descr: The soul of Hugh Capet on the terrace of greed cites her poverty as a spiritual lesson.

name: Souls on the terrace of sloth quote her "haste" (Luke 1
description: 39) as a spiritual lesson. Purg. XVIII, 99–100.
ref_descr: Called the "only bride the Holy Spirit has known" in reference to the Incarnation.

name: Her call for more wine at the marriage at Cana (John 2
description: 3) was for decorum and not because she wanted more wine. Lesson in temperance heard spoken from the tree on the terrace of the gluttonous. Purg. XXII, 142–144.
ref_descr: Cited as an example in sexual abstinence by souls on the terrace of the lustful.

name: Master Adam
description: Possibly an Englishman, who came to Bologna by way of Brescia. He was employed by the Guidi, counts of Romena, to counterfeit the Florentine florin. Stamped with the image of John the Baptist, the florin contained 24 karats of gold. His contained 21, for which crime he was burned at the stake in 1281.
ref_descr: Among the falsifiers, he points out two liars, Potiphar's wife and Sinon, with whom he exchanges insults.

name: Matilda
description: Sole permanent resident of the Terrestrial Paradise.
ref_descr: Dante encounters her gathering flowers on the banks of the River Lethe.

name: Saint Matthias
description: After Judas' betrayal and suicide, he took his place as one of the Twelve Apostles (Acts of the Apostles I:23–26). Late legends state he was either crucified in Colchis or stoned by the Jews.
ref_descr: How he became an apostle is contrasted with the Simoniacs.

name: Medea
description: Mythical daughter of Aeetes, king of Colchis, she helped Jason get the Golden Fleece, but was abandoned by him. She took revenge by killing their two children.
ref_descr: For her also is Jason punished.

name: Metellus
description: Lucius Caecilius Metellus, tribune of the plebs 49 BCE, resisted Julius Caesar when he wanted to plunder the treasury.
ref_descr: Mentioned in connection with the Tarpeian Rock.

name: Michael
description: Archangel
ref_descr: Defeated Satan.

name: Michael
description: Archangel
ref_descr: Souls in Purgatory call on him to pray for them.

name: Michael
description: Archangel
ref_descr: Beatrice tells Dante that Michael may be depicted in human form, but that this form is an accommodation to the limits of the human imagination.

name: Michal
description: daughter of King Saul and wife of King David.
ref_descr: Depicted as an example of arrogance in a wall carving in Purgatory.

name: Midas
description: legendary Phrygian king who greedily asked that all he touched be turned to gold.
ref_descr: Cited by souls in the terrace of the greedy as an example of the tragedy of greed.

name: Minos
description: A semi-legendary king of Crete, son of Zeus and Europa. In The Divine Comedy, he sits at the entrance to the second circle in the Inferno, which is the beginning of Hell proper. Here, he judges the sins of each dead soul and assigns it to its rightful punishment by indicating the circle to which it must descend. He does this by circling his tail around his body the appropriate number of times.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante.

name: Minos
description: A semi-legendary king of Crete, son of Zeus and Europa. In The Divine Comedy, he sits at the entrance to the second circle in the Inferno, which is the beginning of Hell proper. Here, he judges the sins of each dead soul and assigns it to its rightful punishment by indicating the circle to which it must descend. He does this by circling his tail around his body the appropriate number of times.
ref_descr: Sends suicides to their appointed punishments.

name: Minos
description: A semi-legendary king of Crete, son of Zeus and Europa. In The Divine Comedy, he sits at the entrance to the second circle in the Inferno, which is the beginning of Hell proper. Here, he judges the sins of each dead soul and assigns it to its rightful punishment by indicating the circle to which it must descend. He does this by circling his tail around his body the appropriate number of times.
ref_descr: Amphiaraus falls down to him.

name: Minos
description: A semi-legendary king of Crete, son of Zeus and Europa. In The Divine Comedy, he sits at the entrance to the second circle in the Inferno, which is the beginning of Hell proper. Here, he judges the sins of each dead soul and assigns it to its rightful punishment by indicating the circle to which it must descend. He does this by circling his tail around his body the appropriate number of times.
ref_descr: He can also speak, to clarify the soul's location within the circle indicated by the wrapping of his tail.

name: Minos
description: A semi-legendary king of Crete, son of Zeus and Europa. In The Divine Comedy, he sits at the entrance to the second circle in the Inferno, which is the beginning of Hell proper. Here, he judges the sins of each dead soul and assigns it to its rightful punishment by indicating the circle to which it must descend. He does this by circling his tail around his body the appropriate number of times.
ref_descr: Who "cannot mistake", condemns Griffolino of Arezzo to the tenth pouch.

name: Minos
description: A semi-legendary king of Crete, son of Zeus and Europa. In The Divine Comedy, he sits at the entrance to the second circle in the Inferno, which is the beginning of Hell proper. Here, he judges the sins of each dead soul and assigns it to its rightful punishment by indicating the circle to which it must descend. He does this by circling his tail around his body the appropriate number of times.
ref_descr: Virgil not bound by Minos because he resides in Limbo.

name: Minotaur
description: In Greek mythology, a creature that was half man and half bull. It was held captive by King Minos of Crete, inside the Labyrinth, an elaborate maze designed by Daedalus. It was slain by Theseus.
ref_descr: Guards the seventh circle.

name: Miserere
description: ("Have mercy.") Incipit of Psalm 51 (Psalm 50 in the Vulgate Bible.) It is one of the Seven Penitential Psalms.
ref_descr: Chanted by souls waiting to enter Purgatory.

name: "Modicum, et non videbitis me; et iterum, modicum, vos videbitis me."
description: ("In a little while, you will not see me; and in a little while, you will see me again."). Spoken by Jesus to his disciples at the Last Supper. John 16:16
ref_descr: Quoted by Beatrice before her departure with Dante into Paradise.

name: Mongibello
description: Sicialian name for Mount Etna, thought to be Vulcan's furnace.
ref_descr: "The sooty forge".

name: Mosca de' Lamberti
description: Ghibelline who in 1215 rekindled feuding with the Guelphs by urging the killing of the Guelph Buondelmonte dei Buondelmonte, for breaking a marriage engagement.
ref_descr: One of a group of famous political Florentines, "who were so worthy ... whose minds bent toward the good", asked about by Dante of Ciacco.

name: Mosca de' Lamberti
description: Ghibelline who in 1215 rekindled feuding with the Guelphs by urging the killing of the Guelph Buondelmonte dei Buondelmonte, for breaking a marriage engagement.
ref_descr: Found among the Sowers of Scandal and Schism in the eighth circle, Ninth Pouch. He was a "seed of evil for the Tuscans".

name: Moses
description: an important prophet in many Abrahamic religions. He was the leader of the Israelites and the purported author of the Torah.
ref_descr: Raised by Jesus from Limbo into Paradise.

name: Mucius
description: Gaius Mucius Scaevola, ancient Roman soldier from a noteworthy family. When captured by enemies, he held his right hand in a fire to show his steadfast willingness to give his life for Rome.
ref_descr: Mentioned by Beatrice as an example of a constant will in the face of adversity.

name: Muhammad (c. 570–632)
description: The founder of Islam.
ref_descr: Found among the "sowers of dissension", he points out his son-in-law Ali, and through Dante, warns Fra Dolcino.

name: Muses
description: In Greek and Roman mythology, the inspiring goddesses of song, poetry and art. It was a standard literary device to invoke their aid when undertaking a difficult writing task.
ref_descr: Dante invokes them nine times in the Comedy.
ref: Inf. II, 7–9, Purg. I, 7, Purg. XXII, 58, Purg. XXIX, 37, Par. II, 8.

name: Myrrha
description: In Greek Mythology mother of Adonis, who in disguise committed incest with her father (Ovid, Metamorphoses, X, 298–502)
ref_descr: Among the falsifiers, "taking another's shape", she "loved her father past the limits of just love".

name: "Neque nubent"
description: ("Nor do they marry.") (Mat 22:30)
ref_descr: Quoted by the penitent soul of Pope Hadrian V in Purgatory to show that worldly honors do not transfer there. Dante had done him reverence on learning his identity.

name: Nicholas
description: Saint and Bishop of Myra in the 4th century. One legend about Nicholas is that he rescued three young poor girls from a life of prostitution by a secret gift of dowries.
ref_descr: Cited by Hugh Capet, who is repenting the terrace of the greedy, as an example of generosity.

name: Pope Nicholas III (c. 1220–1280)
description: Born Giovanni Gaetano Orsini from an eminent Roman family, he was made cardinal by Innocent IV and became pope in 1277, where he distinguished himself for his ability as a politician.
ref_descr: Punished among the Simoniacs for his nepotism. He prophesies to Dante the arrival in Hell of the popes Boniface VIII and Clement V.

name: Nile
description: A major river in northeastern Africa.
ref_descr: Satan's left face is compared to "those who come from where the Nile, descending, flows".

name: Nimrod
description: Great-grandson of Noah. According to Genesis, he was a "mighty hunter" and King of Shinar. Legends about him have him in charge of building the Tower of Babel.
ref_descr: Encountered chained in the "Well of the Giants," where he speaks only gibberish.

name: Nimrod
description: Great-grandson of Noah. According to Genesis, he was a "mighty hunter" and King of Shinar. Legends about him have him in charge of building the Tower of Babel.
ref_descr: Depicted on the pavement in Purgatory as an exemplar of arrogance. He is shown at the foot of the Tower of Babel.

name: Nimrod
description: Great-grandson of Noah. According to Genesis, he was a "mighty hunter" and King of Shinar. Legends about him have him in charge of building the Tower of Babel.
ref_descr: Mentioned by Adam as he explains the extinction of his own language occurring before Nimrod's aborted construction project.

name: Ninus
description: Mythical king of Assyria and eponymous founder of Nineveh, he was the husband of Semiramis.
ref_descr: Remembered as predecessor of Semiramis on the throne of Assyria.

name: Niobe
description: Queen of Thebes, whose seven sons and seven daughters were killed by Apollo and Diana after Niobe boasted she was superior to their mother Latona.
ref_descr: Depicted in the pavement carvings in Purgatory as an example of arrogance.

name: Noah
description: Biblical patriarch. He is best known for building the Ark to save mankind and land animals from extinction during the Flood.
ref_descr: Raised by Jesus from Limbo into Paradise.

name: Obizzo II d'Este
description: Marquess of Ferrara in 1264–1293 and a leading Guelph. Popular tradition had it that he was killed by his son, Azzo VIII.
ref_descr: Pointed out by Nessus.

name: Obizzo II d'Este
description: Marquess of Ferrara in 1264–1293 and a leading Guelph. Popular tradition had it that he was killed by his son, Azzo VIII.
ref_descr: The "marquis" for whom Venedico Caccianemico admits to have procured his sister Ghisolabella.

name: Oderisi of Gubbio
description: 13th-century manuscript illuminator. None of his works survive.
ref_descr: Encountered in Purgatory among the prideful.

name: Odysseus (Ulysses in Roman mythology)
description: King of Ithaca, he was the son of Laertes, husband of Penelope and father of Telemachus. Known for his guile and resourcefulness, he is the hero of Homer's Odyssey, and a major character in the Iliad. During the Trojan War, with Diomedes, he stole the Palladium and conceived the trickery of the Trojan horse. He was famous for the twenty years it took him to return home from the war.
ref_descr: Among the advisors of fraud, he (Ulysses) is punished with Diomedes for the sins they both committed at Troy.

name: Odysseus (Ulysses in Roman mythology)
description: King of Ithaca, he was the son of Laertes, husband of Penelope and father of Telemachus. Known for his guile and resourcefulness, he is the hero of Homer's Odyssey, and a major character in the Iliad. During the Trojan War, with Diomedes, he stole the Palladium and conceived the trickery of the Trojan horse. He was famous for the twenty years it took him to return home from the war.
ref_descr: At Virgil's urging, he (Ulysses) speaks about his journey after leaving Circe.

name: Odysseus (Ulysses in Roman mythology)
description: King of Ithaca, he was the son of Laertes, husband of Penelope and father of Telemachus. Known for his guile and resourcefulness, he is the hero of Homer's Odyssey, and a major character in the Iliad. During the Trojan War, with Diomedes, he stole the Palladium and conceived the trickery of the Trojan horse. He was famous for the twenty years it took him to return home from the war.
ref_descr: Mentioned by the siren who tempts Dante in a dream.

name: "Oh, my son, why have you done this to us?"
description: Mary's speaks to her young son Jesus when he remained in Jerusalem without their knowledge or permission. (Luke 2:48)
ref_descr: Seen in a vision by Dante as an example of patience as he enters the terrace of the angry in Purgatory.

name: "OMO"
description: Letters seen formed by the eyes and nose-bridge of an emaciated human face. "Homo" in Latin means "human," and in Italian the word is "Uomo."
ref_descr: Dante sees the letters in the faces of the fasting souls on the terrace of the gluttonous.

name: Sinibaldo degli Ordelaffi
description: Head of the noble Ordelaffi family and ruler of Forlì and the surrounding territory in Romagna from the end of the 13th century. His coat of arms contained a green lion.
ref_descr: Forlì "beneath green paws".

name: Orestes
description: Son of Agamemnon and Clytemnestra. Orestes avenged his father's murder by killing his mother. He refused to let his friend Pylades take the blame for the act.
ref_descr: "I am Orestes" is heard by souls in the terrace of the envious as a lesson in generosity.

name: Paulus Orosius (c. 385–420)
description: Historian and theologian.  associate of St. Augustine.
ref_descr: Not named, but called "that defender of the Christian days who helped Augustine by his history" by Thomas Aquinas in the sphere of the Sun.

name: Orpheus
description: Mythical Greek singer and poet who, like Dante, descended into the underworld.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Orpheus
description: Mythical Greek singer and poet who, like Dante, descended into the underworld.
ref_descr: Dante sees them side by side in the "Valley of the Princes." Both are late-repenters, waiting to enter Purgatory.

name: Ottaviano degli Ubaldini (c. 1210–1250)
description: Cardinal and prominent Ghibelline who was the only supporter of their cause at the Papal Court at the time of the Battle of Montaperti (see Farinata).
ref_descr: Found among the Epicurean heretics.

name: Ovid
description: Latin poet, whose Metamorphoses, is Dante's principle, mythological source.
ref_descr: One of a group of classical poets (see Homer) encountered in Limbo.

name: Ovid
description: Latin poet, whose Metamorphoses, is Dante's principle, mythological source.
ref_descr: His descriptions of the transformations Cadmus and Arethusa in the Metamorphoses are compared to the transformations of the thieves.

name: Maghinardo Pagani da Susinana
description: Signore of Faenza on the river Lamone, and Imola on the river Santerno. Ghibelline by birth, he was a Guelph in Florence. His coat of arms was a white lion on a blue field.
ref_descr: The "young lion of the white lair".

name: Pageant of Church History
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the history of the Christian Church which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXXII & XXXIII.
ref_descr: An eagle ("the Bird of Jove") attacks the Chariot (the Church), representing the persecutions of Christians by various Roman Emperors.

name: Pageant of Church History
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the history of the Christian Church which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXXII & XXXIII.
ref_descr: A malnourished Fox, representing the various early heresies of the Church, leaps onto the Chariot until it is chased away by "my Lady."

name: Pageant of Church History
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the history of the Christian Church which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXXII & XXXIII.
ref_descr: The Eagle returns and covers the chariot with its feathers, representing the alliance of Church and Roman Empire beginning with the Emperor Constantine I.

name: Pageant of Church History
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the history of the Christian Church which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXXII & XXXIII.
ref_descr: A dragon cuts the chariot in half with its tail and drags away half, representing the Islamic conquests during the early centuries of Islam.

name: Pageant of Church History
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the history of the Christian Church which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXXII & XXXIII.
ref_descr: The chariot is covered and choked with weeds, representing the institutional corruptions of the church and the confusion of temporal and spiritual authorities.

name: Pageant of Church History
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the history of the Christian Church which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXXII & XXXIII.
ref_descr: A harlot appears in the chariot, accompanied by an amorous giant. The harlot, an allusion to Revelation 17, represents the corrupted church, while the giant represents Philip IV of France, who removed the papacy from Rome to Avignon in France in 1307.

name: Pageant of the Church Triumphant
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the Church Triumphant which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXIX & XXX.
ref_descr: Seven large candelabras emitting rainbow smoke, representing the Seven Gifts of the Holy Spirit.

name: Pageant of the Church Triumphant
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the Church Triumphant which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXIX & XXX.
ref_descr: Twenty-four elders dressed in white, representing the 24 books of the Old Testament.

name: Pageant of the Church Triumphant
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the Church Triumphant which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXIX & XXX.
ref_descr: Four beasts with multiple wings and eyes (Lion, Ox, Eagle, & Angel), representing the four Gospels. Ancient tradition associates the four beasts seen in the visions of Ezekiel (Ezekiel 1:4–14) and John (Revelation 4:6–8) to the four Gospels.

name: Pageant of the Church Triumphant
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the Church Triumphant which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXIX & XXX.
ref_descr: A Griffin drawing a chariot, representing Christ leading the Church.

name: Pageant of the Church Triumphant
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the Church Triumphant which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXIX & XXX.
ref_descr: A group of three women dancing beside the right wheel, representing the Three Theological Virtues.

name: Pageant of the Church Triumphant
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the Church Triumphant which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXIX & XXX.
ref_descr: A group of four women dancing beside the left wheel, representing the Four Cardinal Virtues.

name: Pageant of the Church Triumphant
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the Church Triumphant which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXIX & XXX.
ref_descr: Saint Luke, dressed as a physician, and Saint Paul, bearing a sword.

name: Pageant of the Church Triumphant
description: Elaborate allegorical representation of the Church Triumphant which Dante witnesses in Purgatory. Purg. XXIX & XXX.
ref_descr: The four authors of the "General Epistles." Finally, the author of the Apocalypse.

name: Palladium
description: A statue of Pallas Athena. Since it was believed that Troy could not be captured while it contained this statue, Odysseus (Ulysses) and Diomedes stole it during the Trojan War (Aeneid II, 228–240).
ref_descr: Its theft is one of the things for which Ulysses and Diomedes are punished.

name: Pallas
description: Legendary ancient Roman youth who bravely fought and died for the liberties of early Rome. His story is recounted in the Aeneid, Book X.
ref_descr: Cited by the soul of Emperor Justinian as the first example of the virtuous Roman.

name: Paolo and Francesca
description: Brother and wife, respectively, of Giovanni Malatesta. The pair were lovers and reputedly killed by Giovanni. Francesca was the daughter of Guido da Polenta.
ref_descr: Found among the sexual sinners.

name: Montagna de' Parcitati
description: Of the noble Parcitati family, he was head of the Ghibelline faction in Rimini until Malatesta da Verrucchio assumed control of the town in 1295. Montagna was first jailed and then treacherously murdered by Malatesta and his son Malatestino.
ref_descr: His abuse by the "mastiffs of Verruchio".

name: Paris
description: Trojan, son of Priam and Hecuba, brother of Hector, and abductor of Helen.
ref_descr: Found amongst the sexual sinners.

name: Parnassus
description: Mountain in Greece near Delphi associated with Apollo and the Muses.
ref_descr: Statius "drank in the cave of Parnassus" as he learned poetry from reading Virgil.

name: Parnassus
description: Mountain in Greece near Delphi associated with Apollo and the Muses.
ref_descr: Dante asks Apollo to grant him inspiration from both peaks of Parnassus to undertake writing the Paradiso.

name: Pasiphaë
description: Wife of King Minos of Crete and mother of the Minotaur. According to Virgil's Eclogue VI, 45–60, she conceived by a bull while hiding inside a hollow wooden cow.
ref_descr: Cited penitentially by souls on the terrace of the lustful.

name: Paternoster
description: The "Lord's Prayer" taught by Jesus to his disciples.
ref_descr: Dante is asked to say the prayer when he returns home to assist the passage of souls in Purgatory.

name: Penelope
description: Faithful wife of Odysseus (Ulysses) king of Ithaca, refusing the many suitors who invaded her home, she waited twenty years for him to return home from the Trojan War.
ref_descr: Not even Ulysses' love for his wife (and son and father) was enough to overrule his desire "to gain experience of the world and of the vices and the worth of men".

name: Penthesilea
description: Queen of the Amazons, she fought on for Troy during the Trojan War.
ref_descr: Seen in Limbo.

name: Pelorus
description: northeast promontory of Sicily.
ref_descr: Mentioned as severed from the Apennine Range.

name: Persius
description: Aulus Persius Flaccus. Roman writer of the 1st century BCE
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Saint Peter
description: One of the apostles of Jesus, and first pope.
ref_descr: "la porta di San Pietro" ("the gateway of Saint Peter").

name: Saint Peter
description: One of the apostles of Jesus, and first pope.
ref_descr: In contrast to the Simoniacs, he paid no gold, to become head of the church, nor did he ask for any from Saint Matthias to make him an apostle.

name: Saint Peter
description: One of the apostles of Jesus, and first pope.
ref_descr: Souls in Purgatory call on Peter to pray for them.

name: St. Peter's Pine Cone
description: A colossal bronze pine cone cast in the 1st or 2nd century CE in Rome. Originally located in the Campus Martius, it is now located in a courtyard in the Vatican Museum.
ref_descr: Dante compares it to the dimensions of Nimrod's head.

name: Phaëton
description: In Greek mythology, the son of Helios, the sun god. To prove his paternity, he asked his father to allow him to drive the chariot of the sun for one day. Unable to control the horses, Phaëton almost destroyed the earth, but was killed by Zeus.
ref_descr: Used as a simile for fear in

name: Phaëton
description: In Greek mythology, the son of Helios, the sun god. To prove his paternity, he asked his father to allow him to drive the chariot of the sun for one day. Unable to control the horses, Phaëton almost destroyed the earth, but was killed by Zeus.
ref_descr: Used as a reference to the sun.

name: Philip IV of France (1268–1314)
description: King from 1285, his reign is memorable for many reasons. In particular he is famous for having shattered the temporal ambitions of the popes.
ref_descr: Probably an allusion to the accusation that Clement V had got his pontificate by promising to pay Philip.

name: Phlegethon
description: "River of fire", in Greek mythology, one of the rivers of Hades.
ref_descr: Boiling river of blood.

name: Phlegethon
description: "River of fire", in Greek mythology, one of the rivers of Hades.
ref_descr: Encountered and described.

name: Phlegethon
description: "River of fire", in Greek mythology, one of the rivers of Hades.
ref_descr: Formed from the tears of the statue of the Old Man of Crete.

name: Phlegethon
description: "River of fire", in Greek mythology, one of the rivers of Hades.
ref_descr: Identified as the "red stream boiling".

name: Phlegethon
description: "River of fire", in Greek mythology, one of the rivers of Hades.
ref_descr: Its deafening roar compared to the waterfall near the monastery of San Benedetto dell'Alpe.

name: Phoenix
description: Mythical bird, which at the end of its life-cycle, burns itself to ashes, from which a reborn phoenix arises.
ref_descr: Its description here is derived from Ovid's Metamorphoses (XV, 392–407).

name: Pia de' Tolomei
description: A Sienese woman allegedly murdered by her husband, Paganello de' Pannocchieschi, who had her thrown from a window in Maremma.
ref_descr: She asks for Dante's prayers when he encounters her waiting to enter Purgatory among souls who died suddenly and unprepared. "Son Pia, Siena mi fé, disfecemi Maremma." ("I am Pia. Siena made me; Maremma unmade me.")

name: Piccarda
description: Sister of Dante's friend Forese Donati who failed to carry out her lifelong monastic vow.
ref_descr: In the sphere of the moon, she explains to Dante the varieties of blessedness among those in Paradise.

name: Pier da Medicina
description: Apparently a political intriguer in Romagna, of whom little is known. Early commentators say he sowed discord between the Malatesta and Polenta families.
ref_descr: Foretells the betrayal and doom of Guido and Angiolello, and points out Curio.

name: Pier da Medicina
description: Apparently a political intriguer in Romagna, of whom little is known. Early commentators say he sowed discord between the Malatesta and Polenta families.
ref_descr: Punished amongst the suicides in

name: Pier Pettinaio
description: (1180–1289) Sienese comb-seller remembered for his piety and honesty. Siena established a festival in his memory.
ref_descr: Sapia, a woman among the envious in Purgatory, says that his prayers have assisted her.

name: Pierides
description: Daughters of Pierus, king of ancient Macedon, who entered into a contest with the Muses.
ref_descr: Mentioned in Purgatory.

name: Pilate
description: Roman governor of Judea, responsible for the crucifixion of Jesus.
ref_descr: Philip IV of France compared to Pilate in his humiliation of Pope Boniface VIII.

name: Pillars of Hercules
description: Name given to the promontories—the Rock of Gibraltar in Europe and Monte Hacho near Ceuta in Africa—that flank the entrance to the Strait of Gibraltar. According to legend, Heracles (Hercules), on his way to steal the cattle of Geryon split a mountain in half, thereby forming the Strait of Gibraltar and connecting the Atlantic Ocean to the Mediterranean. The pillars marked the western boundary of the classical world, beyond which it was unsafe to sail.
ref_descr: Ulysses describes sailing past these "boundary stones" to the see the world which "lies beyond the sun".

name: Pinamonte dei Bonacolsi
description: An able and shrewd politician he took advantage of the fights between Guelphs and Ghibellins that were dividing Mantua to establish himself in 1273 as supreme ruler of the city, founding a Signoria that was kept by his family until 1328.
ref_descr: His deviousness in ousting Alberto da Casalodi.

name: Pisistratus
description: Athenian tyrant of the 6th century BCE. His wife angrily demanded the life of a young man seen publicly embracing their daughter. Pisistratus refused to succumb to anger and gives a mild reply.
ref_descr: Seen by Dante in a vision as he enters the terrace of the angry in Purgatory.

name: Pistoia
description: A Tuscan town which in Dante's time had lost much of its autonomy, becoming a sort of Florentine dependency.
ref_descr: Vanni Fucci prophesies the exile of the Black Guelphs from the town.

name: Pistoia
description: A Tuscan town which in Dante's time had lost much of its autonomy, becoming a sort of Florentine dependency.
ref_descr: Invective against the town.

name: Plato
description: Greek philosopher and teacher of Aristotle. In Dante's day, his writings were less influential than those of his student.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Plato
description: Greek philosopher and teacher of Aristotle. In Dante's day, his writings were less influential than those of his student.
ref_descr: Mentioned by Virgil as one "who would—if reason could—have been content".

name: Plato
description: Greek philosopher and teacher of Aristotle. In Dante's day, his writings were less influential than those of his student.
ref_descr: Beatrice corrects Dante's mistaken ideas about the eternal destiny of souls which he gathered from Plato's Timaeus.

name: Plautus
description: Roman poet of the 2nd century BCE.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Pola
description: Italian seaport (now part of Croatia) famed for its Roman necropolis.
ref_descr: Simile for the tombs in the sixth circle.

name: Polycletus
description: Ancient Greek sculptor, famous for his realism.
ref_descr: Wall carvings in Purgatory compared to his work.

name: Polymestor
description: Ancient king of Thrace. He killed Polydorus, young son of the Trojan King Priam, to steal the treasure that the boy possessed.
ref_descr: Cited by souls on the terrace of the greedy as an example of greed.

name: Polyxena
description: Trojan daughter of Priam and Hecuba. In some accounts, Achilles fell in love with her, and was killed while visiting her. At the demand of Achilles' ghost, Polyxena is sacrificed on Achilles' tomb.
ref_descr: With whom "Achilles finally met love—in his last battle".

name: Polyxena
description: Trojan daughter of Priam and Hecuba. In some accounts, Achilles fell in love with her, and was killed while visiting her. At the demand of Achilles' ghost, Polyxena is sacrificed on Achilles' tomb.
ref_descr: Her death helps drive Hecuba mad with fury.

name: Pompey
description: Pompey "the Great" (106–48 BCE). Famous patrician Roman general.
ref_descr: Cited as a virtuous Roman in the days of the Roman Republic.

name: Priam
description: King of Troy, husband of Hecuba, father of Hector and Paris.
ref_descr: King when Troy was brought down.

name: Priam
description: King of Troy, husband of Hecuba, father of Hector and Paris.
ref_descr: Asked Sinion to tell the truth about the Trojan horse.

name: Priscian
description: Eminent Latin grammarian active in the 6th century who wrote the Institutiones grammaticae, extremely popular in the Middle Ages.
ref_descr: One of a group of sodomites identified by Brunetto Latini to Dante.

name: Proserpina
description: Roman goddess whose story is the myth of springtime. She was the daughter of Ceres and wife of Pluto, king of the underworld. In Greek mythology her name is Persephone.
ref_descr: "Queen of never-ending lamentation".

name: Proserpina
description: Roman goddess whose story is the myth of springtime. She was the daughter of Ceres and wife of Pluto, king of the underworld. In Greek mythology her name is Persephone.
ref_descr: Moon goddess whose face is "kindled" once a month.

name: Proserpina
description: Roman goddess whose story is the myth of springtime. She was the daughter of Ceres and wife of Pluto, king of the underworld. In Greek mythology her name is Persephone.
ref_descr: When Dante sees Matilda gathering flowers in the Terrestrial Paradise, he is reminded that Proserpina was doing the same when he was abducted by Pluto.

name: Ptolemy
description: Greek geographer, astronomer, and astrologer. His geocentric theory of the universe was the standard astronomical model of Dante's day.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Ptolemy son of Abubus
description: Official in the early Hasmonean kingdom which then controlled Judea.
ref_descr: The third ring of Cocytus, where the treacherous to guests are punished, is named Ptolomea.

name: Puccio Sciancato
description: Of the noble Ghibelline Florentine Galigai family, he was exiled in 1268 after the Guelphs' triumph, but accepted the peace brokered in 1280 by Cardinal Latino to reconcile the factions. He was nicknamed Sciancato ("lame").
ref_descr: Among the thieves.

name: Pygmalion
description: Ancient King of Tyre. He murdered his uncle and brother-in-law to obtain their wealth.
ref_descr: Remembered as an example of greed by souls in the terrace of the greedy.

name: Pyrrhus
description: Either Achilles's son Neoptolemus, killer of Priam and many other Trojans, or Pyrrhus of Epirus, could be intended, although the latter was praised by Dante in his Monarchy (II, ix, 8).
ref_descr: Pointed out by Nessus.

name: Pyrrhus
description: Either Achilles's son Neoptolemus, killer of Priam and many other Trojans, or Pyrrhus of Epirus, could be intended, although the latter was praised by Dante in his Monarchy (II, ix, 8).
ref_descr: Pyrrhus of Epirus cited as an early enemy of Rome.

name: "Qui lugent"
description: ("Who mourn") An abbreviation of "Beati qui lugent quoniam ipsi consolabuntur." ("Blessed are they who mourn, for they shall be comforted") (Mat 5:4; 5:5 in the Vulgate)
ref_descr: Spoken by an angel as Dante passes out of the terrace of the slothful.

name: Quintius
description: Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus (520–430 BCE). Ancient Roman noble who assumed dictatorial powers in a crisis and then promptly relinquished them to return to his farm. The city of Cincinnati, Ohio, is named in his honor.
ref_descr: Cited as an exemplar of ancient Roman virtue.

name: Rachel
description: Sister to Leah, second wife of Jacob, and mother of two of the tribes of ancient Israel, including Joseph and Benjamin. She was the more attractive of the two sisters, but Jacob was tricked into marrying Leah first. (Gen 29:16–25) She symbolises the contemplative life in the Comedy.
ref_descr: Companion of Beatrice in Heaven.

name: Rachel
description: Sister to Leah, second wife of Jacob, and mother of two of the tribes of ancient Israel, including Joseph and Benjamin. She was the more attractive of the two sisters, but Jacob was tricked into marrying Leah first. (Gen 29:16–25) She symbolises the contemplative life in the Comedy.
ref_descr: Raised by Jesus from Limbo into Paradise.

name: Rachel
description: Sister to Leah, second wife of Jacob, and mother of two of the tribes of ancient Israel, including Joseph and Benjamin. She was the more attractive of the two sisters, but Jacob was tricked into marrying Leah first. (Gen 29:16–25) She symbolises the contemplative life in the Comedy.
ref_descr: In a dream, Dante hears Leah mention her beautiful sister.

name: Rahab
description: A gentile woman who lived in Jericho in the Promised Land. She assisted the Israelites in capturing the city by hiding two men who had been sent to scout the city prior to their attack.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in the third circle of heaven.

name: Rehoboam
description: King of ancient Israel. He was the son of Solomon and succeeded him on the throne. Because of his oppressive taxation, the northern tribes revolted and formed an independent kingdom.
ref_descr: Depicted on the pavement in Purgatory as example of arrogance.

name: "Rejoice, you who have overcome." ("Godi tu che vinci!")
description: A paraphrase combining "Rejoice and be exceeding glad," (Mat 5:12) with "To him that overcometh will I give to eat of the tree of life" (Rev 2:7).
ref_descr: Heard by Dante in Purgatory as he departs the terrace of the envious.

name: Rinier da Corneto and Rinier Pazzo
description: Highwaymen who lived in Dante's day. Pazzo was excommunicated by Pope Clement IV, in 1268
ref_descr: Pointed out by Nessus.

name: Richard of St. Victor
description: One of the most important 12th-century mystic theologicans. A Scot, he was prior of the famous Augustinian abbey of Saint-Victor in Paris from 1162 until his death in 1173. His writings on mystical contemplation won him the title "Magnus Contemplator", the great contemplator.
ref_descr: "He whose meditation made him more than man".

name: Rubaconte
description: Former name of the bridge now known as Ponte alle Grazie in Florence. Located at the foot of a hill.
ref_descr: Compared to the path of ascent in Purgatory.

name: Rubaconte
description: Former name of the bridge now known as Ponte alle Grazie in Florence. Located at the foot of a hill.
ref_descr: Dante sees him in the "Valley of the Princes," waiting to enter Purgatory. Rudolph is described as "he who neglected that which he ought to have done", perhaps a reference to his failure to come to Italy to be crowned Emperor by the Pope.

name: Jacopo Rusticucci
description: Florentine Guelph of Guido Cavalcanti's guild, active in politics and diplomacy.
ref_descr: One of a group of famous political Florentines, "who were so worthy ... whose minds bent toward the good", asked about by Dante of Ciacco.

name: Jacopo Rusticucci
description: Florentine Guelph of Guido Cavalcanti's guild, active in politics and diplomacy.
ref_descr: One of a group of three Florentine sodomites who approach Dante, and are much esteemed by him.

name: Blames his wife for his sin
description: '"e certo fu la fiera moglie più ch'altro mi nuoce". Inf. XVI, 43–45.
ref_descr: Questions Dante about Borsiere's reports of the moral decay of Florence, which have caused great anguish for him and his companions.

name: Blames his wife for his sin
description: '"e certo fu la fiera moglie più ch'altro mi nuoce". Inf. XVI, 43–45.
ref_descr: Represents (with the other two sodomites) past civic virtue, providing an opportunity for Dante to rail against "La gente nuova e i sùbiti guadagni" ("newcomers and quick gains"), as the cause of Florentine decadence.

name: Sabellus and Nasidius
description: Two soldiers of Cato's army in Lucan's poem Pharsalia (IX, 761–804), who are bitten by snakes, while marching in the Libyan Desert, after which their bodies "transform". Sabellus' transforms into a rotting formless mass; Nasidius' swells, then bursts.
ref_descr: Their cruel fate is compared to that of the thieves.

name: Saladin
description: 12th-century Kurdish Muslim leader renowned for his military prowess, generosity, and merciful attitude to his opponents during the Crusades.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Salve Regina
description: Hymn to the Virgin Mary used in evening services. The song addresses Mary from "the vale of tears."
ref_descr: Sung at sunset by souls in waiting to enter Purgatory in the "Valley of the Princes."

name: Samaria
description: Region north of Jerusalem and west of the Jordan River. According to John 4:4–28, Jesus encountered a Samaritan woman at a well. Their dialogue is about spiritual thirst.
ref_descr: Dante's eagerness to learn the meaning of the earthquake in Purgatory is compared to spiritual thirst.

name: Sardinia
description: Italian Island north of Tunisia and south of Corsica. In Dante's time it was plagued by malaria.
ref_descr: Sickness from July until September.

name: Sannella
description: (Simonetti della Sannella) Italian noble family, latter known as Simonetti, one of the ancient Florentine families from the time of Cacciaguida.
ref_descr: Mentioned together with other noble families, such as Arca, Soldanier, Ardinghi, and Bostichi

name: Sapia Salvani
description: 13th-century Sienese noblewoman.
ref_descr: Encountered on the terrace of the envious.

name: Sapphira
description: early Christian woman who died along with her husband after confessing to withholding money promised to the Church (Acts 5:1–11).
ref_descr: Cited as an example of greed by souls on the terrace of the greedy.

name: Satan
description: Biblical angel who embodies evil and is the greatest foe of God and mankind.
ref_descr: Encountered frozen in Cocytus at the center of the earth.

name: Satan
description: Biblical angel who embodies evil and is the greatest foe of God and mankind.
ref_descr: Depicted in a pavement carving falling from heaven as an exemplar of arrogance.

name: Saturn
description: Seventh and outermost planet in the geocentric planetary theory in Dante's day.
ref_descr: Known as the "cold planet," it and the moon draw heat away from the earth at night.

name: Saul
description: First king of ancient Israel. He died by falling on his own sword after losing a battle at Gilboa.
ref_descr: Depicted on the pavement in Purgatory as an exemplar of arrogance.

name: Gianni Schicchi
description: Disguised as the Florentine Buoso Donati, who had just died, he dictated a new will, bequeathing to himself Donati's best mare.
ref_descr: With his tusks he drags off Capocchio, after which Griffolino of Arezzo tells of Schicchi's impersonation.

name: Scipio
description: Roman general (236–183 BCE) who defeated Hannibal at the Battle of Zama.
ref_descr: The giant Antaeus lived in the valley where the battle of Zama was fought.

name: Scipio
description: Roman general (236–183 BCE) who defeated Hannibal at the Battle of Zama.
ref_descr: Cited as a hero of the Roman Republic.

name: Scorpius
description: Constellation in the form of a Scorpion and sign of the Zodiac.
ref_descr: Dante sees stars at dawn "in the form of an animal that assails with its tail."

name: Scorpius
description: Constellation in the form of a Scorpion and sign of the Zodiac.
ref_descr: Scorpius is on the meridian line when Dante enters the terrace of the lustful. Hence is it 2 P.M. in Purgatory.

name: Michael Scot (c. 1175–1234)
description: Scottish mathematician, philosopher, alchemist and astrologer, honoured by popes and emperors, especially Frederick II, he developed a popular reputation as a magician and seer.
ref_descr: Damned among the soothsayers. Of him it is said "che veramente de le magiche frode seppe 'l gioco" ("of a verity of magical illusions knew the game.")

name: Second Punic War
description: The second of the wars fought between Carthage and Rome (219–202). According to Livy, Hannibal sent to Carthage "a pile" of gold rings from the fingers of thousands of slaughtered Romans.
ref_descr: "The long war where massive mounds of rings were battle spoils".

name: Semiramis
description: Legendary figure who was, in Dante's day, believed to have been sexually licentious after the death of her husband Ninus.
ref_descr: Found amongst the sexual sinners.

name: Seneca, Lucius Annaeus (c. 4 BCE – 65 CE)
description: Roman philosopher, statesman and dramatist, forced to commit suicide by Nero for his participation in the Pisonian conspiracy, called "morale" (moral), by Dante.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Sennacherib
description: King of Assyria (705–681 BCE). His failed siege of Jerusalem is discussed in II Kings, which notes the army's destruction by a plague sent by God and his later assassination by his sons.
ref_descr: Depicted on the pavement in Purgatory as an example of arrogance.

name: Serchio
description: A river near Lucca.
ref_descr: Leisurely floating on ones back in this river is contrasted, by the Malebranche, with the different kind of swimming by the barrators in the lake of boiling pitch.

name: Seven Deadly Sins
description: A list developed by Christian moralists of the principal vices. They include Pride (superbia), Greed (avaritia), Lust (luxuria), Envy (invidia), Gluttony (gula), Anger (ira), and Sloth (acedia).
ref_descr: Pride is "hope of excellence through the abasement of another."

name: Seven Deadly Sins
description: A list developed by Christian moralists of the principal vices. They include Pride (superbia), Greed (avaritia), Lust (luxuria), Envy (invidia), Gluttony (gula), Anger (ira), and Sloth (acedia).
ref_descr: Envy is "love of misfortune" of another when the other excels.

name: Seven Deadly Sins
description: A list developed by Christian moralists of the principal vices. They include Pride (superbia), Greed (avaritia), Lust (luxuria), Envy (invidia), Gluttony (gula), Anger (ira), and Sloth (acedia).
ref_descr: Anger is "seeking another's harm" after being injured by another.

name: Seven Deadly Sins
description: A list developed by Christian moralists of the principal vices. They include Pride (superbia), Greed (avaritia), Lust (luxuria), Envy (invidia), Gluttony (gula), Anger (ira), and Sloth (acedia).
ref_descr: Sloth is love for the Good which is "slack."

name: Seven Deadly Sins
description: A list developed by Christian moralists of the principal vices. They include Pride (superbia), Greed (avaritia), Lust (luxuria), Envy (invidia), Gluttony (gula), Anger (ira), and Sloth (acedia).
ref_descr: Greed, Gluttony & Lust are "excessive self-abandonment" (troppo s'abbandona) to the lesser goods of possessions, food & drink, and sexual desire.

name: Sextus Pompeius
description: Son of Pompey the Great and opponent of Julius Caesar, portrayed by Lucan as a cruel pirate (Pharsalia VI, 420–422).
ref_descr: Pointed out by Nessus.

name: Sichaeus
description: First husband of Dido and ruler of Tyre, he was murdered by Dido's brother.
ref_descr: It is remembered that Dido "ruppe fede al cener di Sicheo" ("broke faith with the ashes of Sichaeus").

name: Sicilian bull
description: A brazen figure of a bull used as an instrument of torture. The echoing screams of its victims, roasting inside, were thought to imitate the bellowing of a bull. It was created by Perillus for the tyrant Phalaris. Its creator was also its first victim.
ref_descr: It "would always bellow with its victims voice".

name: Silvester I
description: A saint, he was Pope from 314 to 335. In the Middle Ages, supported by a forged document called the "Donation of Constantine", it was believed that he had baptized Constantine and cured him of leprosy, and as a result, that he and his successors had been granted rule over Rome and the Western Roman Empire. For Dante, this event was the beginning of the ever-increasing worldly wealth and power of the papacy, and the corruption that went along with it.
ref_descr: "The first rich father!"

name: Silvester I
description: A saint, he was Pope from 314 to 335. In the Middle Ages, supported by a forged document called the "Donation of Constantine", it was believed that he had baptized Constantine and cured him of leprosy, and as a result, that he and his successors had been granted rule over Rome and the Western Roman Empire. For Dante, this event was the beginning of the ever-increasing worldly wealth and power of the papacy, and the corruption that went along with it.
ref_descr: Guido da Montefeltro compares Silvester being sought by Constantine to cure his leprosy, with himself being sought by Boniface to "ease the fever of his arrogance".

name: Simon Magus
description: The magician (or proto-Gnostic) of Samaria. In the Acts of the Apostles (8:9–24) he is rejected by the apostle Peter for trying to buy the ability to confer the Holy Spirit. From his name is derived the word Simony.
ref_descr: His followers "fornicate for gold and silver".

name: Simonides
description: Greek poet of the 5th century BCE.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Simony
description: Sin of selling or paying for offices or positions in the church hierarchy (cf. barratry).
ref_descr: One of the sins of ordinary fraud punished in the eighth circle.

name: Simony
description: Sin of selling or paying for offices or positions in the church hierarchy (cf. barratry).
ref_descr: Dante arrives in the 3rd Bolgia of the eighth circle where the Simoniacs are set upside-down in rock pits, with their exposed feet in flames.

name: Siren
description: Seductive chimera, half-woman and half-bird, who lures sailors to shipwreck on rocks with her singing.
ref_descr: Appears to Dante in a dream.

name: Siren
description: Seductive chimera, half-woman and half-bird, who lures sailors to shipwreck on rocks with her singing.
ref_descr: Beatrice tell Dante that other women are sirens on his spiritual journey.

name: "Sitiunt"
description: ("They thirst.") Abbreviation of "Beati qui esuriunt et sitiunt iustitiam quoniam ipsi saturabuntur." ("Blessed are those who hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be satisfied.") One of the Beatitudes preached by Jesus in Matthew 5.
ref_descr: Heard by Dante as he departed the terrace of the greedy in Purgatory.

name: Socrates
description: Greek philosopher.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Reginaldo Scrovegni
description: One of the richest Paduan bankers. In expiation of his father's sin, his son Enrico commissioned the Cappella degli Scrovegni in 1300 that was frescoed by Giotto.
ref_descr: Among the usurers.

name: Sodom
description: Biblical city, which during the Middle Ages, became associated in Christian thinking with the sin of homosexuality. Sodomy, like usury, was viewed as a sin against nature.
ref_descr: Used to locate the sodomites as being punished in the last ring of the seventh circle.

name: Sodom
description: Biblical city, which during the Middle Ages, became associated in Christian thinking with the sin of homosexuality. Sodomy, like usury, was viewed as a sin against nature.
ref_descr: "Sodom and Gomorrah" is recited penitentially by one group on the terrace of the lustful.

name: Solomon
description: Biblical king,  son of King David,  proverbially the wisest of men.
ref_descr: Not named, but called "the high mind blessed to know to such great depths, no second ever rose who saw so much" by Thomas Aquinas in the sphere of the Sun.

name: Sordello
description: 13th-century Italian troubadour, born in Goito near Virgil's home town Mantua.
ref_descr: In Purgatory he personifies patriotic pride.

name: Statius
description: Publius Papinius Statius (c. 45 – c. 96). Roman poet of the Silver Age and author of the Silvae, the Achilleid and the Thebais.
ref_descr: Dante and Virgil encounter him in the level of Purgatory reserved for the avaricious, and he accompanies them on the rest of their trip through Purgatory.

name: Statius
description: Publius Papinius Statius (c. 45 – c. 96). Roman poet of the Silver Age and author of the Silvae, the Achilleid and the Thebais.
ref_descr: In a story created by Dante, Statius tells how reading Virgil converted him to Christianity. There is no historical evidence that Statius was a Christian.

name: Styx
description: One of the rivers encircling Hades in the Aeneid (VI, 187, 425).
ref_descr: Encountered and described.

name: Styx
description: One of the rivers encircling Hades in the Aeneid (VI, 187, 425).
ref_descr: Formed from the tears of the statue of the Old Man of Crete.

name: "Summae Deus clementiae"
description: ("God of highest mercy.") Latin monastic hymn sung on Saturday mornings. Its third verse calls on God to consume our loins with a fire of divine love.
ref_descr: Sung by souls on the terrace of the lustful in Purgatory.

name: Swallow (Rondinella)
description: Songbird. According to Ovid, Philomela, a princess from Athens, was raped by Tereus and then transformed into a songbird, generally identified as a nightingale.
ref_descr: Dante mentions the bird's song as a harbinger of dawn in Purgatory.

name: Syrinx
description: Mythological Greek nymph who, escaping her sexual defilement, fled to a river and was converted into a hollow reed which sang as the wind blew.
ref_descr: Alluded by Dante as the musical reason for his sleep in Paradise.

name: Tagliacozzo
description: Site of a defeat by Manfred's nephew Conradin, by Charles of Anjou, who, following the advice of his general Erard ("Alardo") de Valery, surprised Conradin, with the use of reserve troops.
ref_descr: "Where old Alardo conquered without weapons".

name: Tarpeian Rock
description: cliff on the Capitoline Hill in Rome, where an ancient temple to Saturn was located.
ref_descr: Compared to the gate of Purgatory.

name: Tarquin
description: Last king of Rome, he was overthrown by Lucius Junius Brutus, considered the founder of the Republic.
ref_descr: Seen in Limbo.

name: Taurus
description: Zodiac constellation in the form of a bull.
ref_descr: When Dante enters the terrace of the lustful in Purgatory, Taurus is on the meridian line. Hence it is 2 P.M. in Purgatory.

name: Te Deum laudamus
description: "We praise Thee, O God." Ancient Latin hymn sung in the morning monastic offices. Also sung in special occasions of celebration.
ref_descr: Heard by Dante as he enters Purgatory.

name: Te lucis ante
description: "To Thee before the close of day." Latin hymn sung at Compline, the final monastic prayer office of the day.
ref_descr: Souls in the "Valley of the Princes" sing the hymn at the end of the day.

name: Telemachus
description: Son of Odysseus (Ulysses) and Penelope, he plays an important role in the Odyssey. In the lost Telegony he appears to have married Circe and been granted immortality.
ref_descr: Not even Ulysses' love for his son (and wife and father) was enough to overrule his desire "to gain experience of the world and of the vices and the worth of men".

name: Temple
description: reference to the Templars, a military order founded during the Crusades.
ref_descr: Forcibly dissolved in 1307 by Philip IV of France to obtain their vast wealth.

name: Terence
description: Publius Terentius Afer. Roman playwright of the 2nd century BCE.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Thebes
description: City of Ancient Greece.
ref_descr: Statius tells Dante and Virgil that he composed the Thebaid, an epic poem on the history of Thebes. "I sang of Thebes."

name: Thaïs
description: A courtesan in Terence's Eunuchus. Perhaps misled by Cicero's commentary (De amicitia XXVI, 98), he places her among the flatterers.
ref_descr: Virgil contemptuously calls her "puttana" ("whore").

name: Thales (c. 635–543 BCE)
description: Greek philosopher.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Thaumas
description: Greek sea god, whose daughter is Iris, the goddess of rainbows.
ref_descr: Statius comments that rainbows do not occur in Purgatory.

name: Themis
description: Greek goddess of divine justice and one of the Oracles of Delphi.
ref_descr: Beatrice compares her own obscure oracles about the future to those of Themis or the Sphinx.

name: Theobald V of Champagne (c. 1238–1270)
description: The eldest son of Theobald IV of Champagne, on his death in 1253 he succeeded him as Count of Champagne and, as Theobald II, king of Navarre. He died childless in 1270.
ref_descr: The "good king Theobald" ("buon re Tebaldo").

name: Theological Virtues
description: Virtues granted to believers by God's grace. They include Faith, Hope and Love.
ref_descr: Symbolized by three stars visible from Purgatory.

name: Theological Virtues
description: Virtues granted to believers by God's grace. They include Faith, Hope and Love.
ref_descr: Symbolized by three women dancing at the right wheel of the chariot in the Pageant of the Church Triumphant.

name: Theseus
description: Legendary king of Athens who visited the underworld and, in the version used by Dante, was rescued by Herakles.
ref_descr: His name invoked by the Erinyes.

name: Theseus
description: Legendary king of Athens who visited the underworld and, in the version used by Dante, was rescued by Herakles.
ref_descr: The "Duke of Athens" who killed the Minotaur.

name: Theseus
description: Legendary king of Athens who visited the underworld and, in the version used by Dante, was rescued by Herakles.
ref_descr: Helped to defeat drunken Centaurs at Hippodamia's wedding feast.

name: Thetis
description: Noble ancient Greek woman. Wife of Peleus and mother of Achilles.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Thisbe
description: In a tale by Ovid (Metamorphoses IV, 55–166), Thisbe and Pyramus are lovers in ancient Babylon separated by a wall.
ref_descr: Dante alludes to them when a wall of fire separates him from Beatrice.

name: Thymbraeus
description: An epithet of Apollo derived from the town Thymbra, where there was a temple dedicated to him.
ref_descr: In Purgatory, Thymbreaus (Apollo) is depicted on the pavement casting Briareus from Olympus.

name: Tiber
description: River which runs through Rome and empties into the Tyrrhenian Sea.
ref_descr: Souls bound for Purgatory wait on the seashore for the angelic ferry.

name: Tigris and Euphrates
description: Rivers in the Middle East. According to Genesis 2, they had their origins in the Garden of Eden.
ref_descr: Dante compares these two rivers to the two rivers he sees in Terrestrial Paradise.

name: Timaeus
description: A dialogue of Plato where the celestial source and destiny of the human soul are discussed.
ref_descr: Beatrice corrects Dante of mistaken ideas he drew from this dialogue.

name: Tiresias
description: A mythical blind soothsayer who was transformed into a woman and then back into a man, seven years later. He has an important role in classical literature, including the Odyssey.
ref_descr: His double transformation is told.

name: Tiresias
description: A mythical blind soothsayer who was transformed into a woman and then back into a man, seven years later. He has an important role in classical literature, including the Odyssey.
ref_descr: Father of Manto.

name: Tithonus
description: Trojan lover of Eos, Titan of the Dawn.
ref_descr: Mentioned in reference to dawn in Purgatory.

name: Titus
description: Roman Emperor (79–81). As a general, he completed the campaign to put down a Jewish revolt and recapture Jerusalem in 70 CE. Par. VI, 92–93.
ref_descr: Statius tells Dante and Virgil that he was from the age of Titus.

name: Tityas
description: Son of Gaia. Tityus was a giant killed by Zeus for attacking Leto.
ref_descr: Seen chained in the "Well of the Giants".

name: Tobit
description: Protagonist of the ancient Jewish book of the same name. Tobit is conducted on a journey by the Archangel Raphael.
ref_descr: Beatrice tells Dante that Raphael may have appeared in human form, but that this form is an accommodation to the limits of the human imagination.

name: Tomyris
description: Queen of the Massagetae in the 6th century BCE. According to Herodotus, Cyrus the Great led a failed invasion of her lands. After his defeat and death in battle, Tomyris plunged his severed head into a wineskin filled with blood.
ref_descr: Cyrus' death is depicted on the pavement in Purgatory as an example of arrogance.

name: Torquatus
description: Titus Manlius Torquatus, Consul and Dictator in Rome during the 4th century, BCE.
ref_descr: Cited as an example of the noble Roman.

name: Trajan
description: Roman Emperor (98–117) at the height of the Empire. According to medieval legend, he was posthumously converted to Christianity by Pope Gregory the Great.
ref_descr: Appears depicted in a wall carving as an exemplar of humility, granting justice to a widow.

name: Troy
description: Also called Ilium, the site of the Trojan War, described in Homer's Iliad, and the home of Aeneas. The Greeks were victorious by means of the wooden Trojan Horse, which the Greeks left as a "gift" for the Trojans. The Trojans brought the horse through the gates into their walled city, and the Greek soldiers who had hid inside the horse were able to open the gates and let in the rest of the Greek army.
ref_descr: Aeneas' escape.

name: Troy
description: Also called Ilium, the site of the Trojan War, described in Homer's Iliad, and the home of Aeneas. The Greeks were victorious by means of the wooden Trojan Horse, which the Greeks left as a "gift" for the Trojans. The Trojans brought the horse through the gates into their walled city, and the Greek soldiers who had hid inside the horse were able to open the gates and let in the rest of the Greek army.
ref_descr: "That horse's fraud that caused a breach".

name: Troy
description: Also called Ilium, the site of the Trojan War, described in Homer's Iliad, and the home of Aeneas. The Greeks were victorious by means of the wooden Trojan Horse, which the Greeks left as a "gift" for the Trojans. The Trojans brought the horse through the gates into their walled city, and the Greek soldiers who had hid inside the horse were able to open the gates and let in the rest of the Greek army.
ref_descr: Trojan (meaning perhaps, through Aeneas, their Samnite descendants) wars in Apulia.

name: Troy
description: Also called Ilium, the site of the Trojan War, described in Homer's Iliad, and the home of Aeneas. The Greeks were victorious by means of the wooden Trojan Horse, which the Greeks left as a "gift" for the Trojans. The Trojans brought the horse through the gates into their walled city, and the Greek soldiers who had hid inside the horse were able to open the gates and let in the rest of the Greek army.
ref_descr: The "pride of Troy ... dared all" but "was destroyed".

name: Troy
description: Also called Ilium, the site of the Trojan War, described in Homer's Iliad, and the home of Aeneas. The Greeks were victorious by means of the wooden Trojan Horse, which the Greeks left as a "gift" for the Trojans. The Trojans brought the horse through the gates into their walled city, and the Greek soldiers who had hid inside the horse were able to open the gates and let in the rest of the Greek army.
ref_descr: Destruction of Troy depicted on the pavement in Purgatory as an example of arrogance.

name: Tristan
description: Hero of medieval French romance, he was a Cornish Knight of the Round Table, and adulterous lover of Isolde.
ref_descr: Found amongst the sexual sinners.

name: Typhon
description: Son of Tartarus and Gaia. Typhon was a giant with a hundred serpent heads.
ref_descr: Seen chained in the "Well of the Giants".

name: Ugolino della Gherardesca
description: Leader of one of two competing Guelph factions in Pisa. In 1288 he conspired with the Archbishop Ruggiere degli Ubaldini to oust the leader of the other faction, his grandson Nino de' Visconti. Ugolino was, in turn, betrayed by Ruggiere and imprisoned with several of his sons and grandsons. They all died of starvation in prison.
ref_descr: Found with Ruggiere amongst those damned for treason.

name: Usury
description: The practice of charging a fee for the use of money; viewed by the medieval church as a sin because it went contrary to the idea that wealth is based on natural increase, which was believed to be a gift from God.
ref_descr: Explained by Virgil to Dante.

name: Usury
description: The practice of charging a fee for the use of money; viewed by the medieval church as a sin because it went contrary to the idea that wealth is based on natural increase, which was believed to be a gift from God.
ref_descr: The usurers are punished in the seventh circle

name: Urania
description: The ancient Muse of Astronomy. She became the Muse of poets describing sacred themes.
ref_descr: Dante invokes her in

name: Varro
description: Either Publius Terentius Varro or Lucius Varius Rufus. Both were Roman writers of the 1st century BCE.
ref_descr: Resident of Limbo.

name: Venetian Arsenal
description: Shipyard and naval depot for Venice, built c. 1104, in Castello sestiere, it was one of the most important shipyards in Europe, and was instrumental in maintaining Venice as a great naval power.
ref_descr: Described.

name: "Veni, sponsa, de Libano"
description: ("Come with me from Lebanon, my spouse.") (Song of Solomon 4:8)
ref_descr: Sung by the elders representing the books of the Old Testament in the Pageant of the Church Triumphant.

name: "Venite, benedicti Patris mei."
description: ("Come, blessed of my Father.") (Mat 25:34)
ref_descr: Sung by an angel as Dante finishes the last purgation.

name: Vespers
description: Evening monastic prayer service. As a reference to a period of time, Vespers is 3 P.M. to 6 P.M.
ref_descr: Used to indicate the time of day.

name: Vexilla regis prodeunt
description: ("The royal banner draws forth.") Medieval Latin hymn.
ref_descr: Virgil introduces Satan with "Vexilla regis produent inferni" ("the king's banners come out of hell").

name: "Vinum non habent"
description: "They have no wine." (John 2:3) Words spoken by Mary to Jesus at the wedding feast at Cana to prompt him to supply more wine for the feast.
ref_descr: Heard by souls in the terrace of the envious as a lesson in generosity.

name: "Virum non cognosco"
description: ("I have not known a man.") The Virgin Mary's response to the angel's announcement of the virgin birth of her son Jesus.
ref_descr: Recited penitentially by souls on the terrace of the lustful in Purgatory.

name: Volto Santo ("Holy face") of Lucca
description: An early Byzantine crucifix made of very dark wood, greatly venerated as having been miraculously created.
ref_descr: Used by the Malebranche to mock the pitch-blackened face and body of one of the barrators (perhaps Bottario).

name: Virgil (Publius Vergilius Maro) (70–19 BCE)
description: Latin poet. He serves as Dante's guide through the Inferno and Purgatorio. In the absence of texts of Homer, the readers in the Middle Ages considered Virgil's Aeneid to be the great epic poem of the Classical world. In Dante's time, many believed that Virgil had predicted the arrival of Christianity in lines from his Eclogue IV: "at the boy's birth in whom/the iron shall cease, the golden race arise" (trans John Dryden). This made him doubly suited to his role as guide. He also symbolises Reason. Virgil accompanies Dante from Inf. I, 61 to Purg. XXX, 54.
ref_descr: Sudden appearance.

ref_descr: In Purgatory, the poet Statius claims that Virgil's Aeneid was his poetic inspiration. It was my "mother" and my "nurse."

description: Latin poet. He serves as Dante's guide through the Inferno and Purgatorio. In the absence of texts of Homer, the readers in the Middle Ages considered Virgil's Aeneid to be the great epic poem of the Classical world. In Dante's time, many believed that Virgil had predicted the arrival of Christianity in lines from his Eclogue IV: "at the boy's birth in whom/the iron shall cease, the golden race arise" (trans John Dryden). This made him doubly suited to his role as guide. He also symbolises Reason. Virgil accompanies Dante from Inf. I, 61 to Purg. XXX, 54.
ref_descr: Departs from Dante without saying farewell.

name: Vitaliano del Dente
description: Paduan banker, he was podestà of Vicenza in 1304 and of Padua in 1307.
ref_descr: His future damnation as a usurer is foretold by Reginaldo Scrovegni.

name: Vulcan
description: In Roman mythology, blacksmith of the gods and, with the help of the Cyclops, maker of thunderbolts for Jove.
ref_descr: From whom Jove "took in wrath the keen-edged thunderbolt".

name: Vulcan
description: In Roman mythology, blacksmith of the gods and, with the help of the Cyclops, maker of thunderbolts for Jove.
ref_descr: Dantes sees him with his father Ottokar II in the "Valley of the Princes". He is a late-repenter waiting to enter Purgatory.

name: Michele Zanche (died 1290)
description: Governor of the giudicato of Logudoro, in Sardinia. He administered the province for King Enzo, son of the Emperor Frederick II. When Enzo was made prisoner in 1249, his wife divorced and married Zanche. The latter ruled Logudoro until 1290, when he was murdered by his son-in-law Branca Doria.
ref_descr: Among the barrators.

name: Zion
description: Mountain in Jerusalem where Solomon's Temple was constructed.
ref_descr: Used as a metonym for Jerusalem.

name: Zeno of Elea (c. 490 – c. 430 BCE)
description: Greek presocratic philosopher.
ref_descr: Encountered by Dante in Limbo.

name: Zeus (also Jove or Jupiter)
description: Chief god of Classical mythology.
ref_descr: Defied by Capaneus, he kills him with a thunderbolt.

name: Zeus (also Jove or Jupiter)
description: Chief god of Classical mythology.
ref_descr: An Eagle ("the bird of Jove"), representing the Roman Empire, attacks the young Church in the Pageant of Church History.

name: Saint Zita (c. 1215–1272)
description: Canonized in 1696, she is the Patron saint of all maids and domestics. In her city, Lucca, she was already, in life, an object of popular devotion and reputed a saint. In Dante's time, her fame had already made her a sort of patron saint of her city. The Elders of Saint Zita were ten citizens of Lucca who, along with the chief magistrate, were the rulers of the city.
ref_descr: An "elder of Saint Zita" (perhaps Bottario) is plunged into a lake of boiling pitch with the barrators.
